PART 1 - GENERAL GOVERNMENT 
CHAPTER 1-4 - THE CITY COUNCIL 

1-4-010 - Regular meetings; special meetings. 
A.  Regular meetings of the city council shall be held on the second Wednesday of each month at 7:00 p.m. in council chambers at 205 Lawrence Street, Marietta, Georgia. City council may hold any regular or special meeting of council at such other time or at such other location as may be called or approved as provided here. 
B.  When the day for a regular meeting falls upon a day which is a legal holiday in this state, the meeting shall be held the next Wednesday or as otherwise set by city council, at which meeting all matters shall be taken up which might have come before the meeting as regularly set. 
C.  Special meetings of the city council may be held on call as provided in the city charter. 
D.  Only business stated in the call may be transacted at a special meeting unless there is unanimous consent of all council members present. 
E.  Notice of any special meeting may be waived by a council member in writing before or after a special meeting, and attendance at the meeting shall also constitute a waiver of notice on any business transacted in the council member's presence. 
F.  Any meeting of the city council may be continued or adjourned from day to day, or for more than one day, but no adjournment shall be for a longer period than until the next regular meeting thereafter. 
(Code 1978, § 1-1001, Ord. No. 3624, 8/8/79, § 1; Ord. No. 4772, 3/14/90, § 1; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
1-4-020 - Public meetings. 
A.  All meetings of the city council or any board, commission or other body of the city shall be open to the public. [1] 
B.  Members of any body covered by this section shall be allowed to bring with them in closed meetings of the body any city employees or officers each may deem necessary; provided, those persons shall not divulge any information so gained without the permission of the full membership of that body and to divulge the information otherwise shall be unlawful. 
(Code 1978, § 1-1002; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
(1) Meetings by the city to discuss or take action on the filling of a vacancy in the membership of an agency shall at all times be open to the public. 
(2) Notice of all meetings prescribing the time, place, and date shall be posted and available to the public. Meetings shall be held in accordance with a regular schedule, but this does not preclude the city from canceling or postponing any regularly scheduled meeting. If the meeting is held other than the regularly scheduled time, due notice of at least twenty-four (24) hours shall be provided in writing at the place of the regularly scheduled meeting along with written or oral notice, including notice by telephone, of at least twenty-four (24) hours to the legal organ, when special circumstances occur and are so declared by the city, less than twenty-four (24) hours notice will be sufficient upon the giving of notice as is reasonable under the circumstances, including notice to the legal organ. The reason for holding the meeting with less than twenty-four (24) hours notice and the nature of the notice shall be recorded in the minutes. The legal organ shall immediately make any notification available upon inquiry to any member of the public. 
(3) Open meetings are not required for the following activities: 
 (a) Staff meetings held for investigative purposes under duties or responsibilities imposed by law; 
 (b) Meetings where the City is discussing the future acquisition of real estate. Disclosure of such portions of the minutes as would identify real estate to be acquired may be delayed until such time as the acquisition of the real estate has been completed, terminated, or abandoned or court proceedings with respect thereto initiated; 
 (c) Meetings when discussing or deliberating upon the appointment, employment, compensation, hiring, disciplinary action or dismissal, or periodic evaluation or ratings of a public officer or employee. The meeting may not be closed, however, when receiving evidence or hearing argument on charges filed to determine disciplinary action or dismissal of a public officer or employee. The vote on any matter covered by this paragraph shall be taken in public and the minutes of the meeting shall be made available; or 
 (d) instructions to or legal advice and information from an attorney representing the city or council. 
(4) Members of any body covered by this section shall be allowed to bring with them in closed meetings of the body any city employees or officers each may deem necessary; provided those persons shall not divulge any information so gained without the permission of the full membership of that body, and to divulge the information shall be unlawful. (O.C.G.A. 50-13-1 et seq.) 

1-4-030 - Advertising costs paid by city; procedure. 
A.  Unless specifically provided otherwise in this code, no advertising required in this code shall be paid for by the city. 
B.  A particular advertisement required by the code may be paid for by the city only upon good cause shown by a petitioner for such and upon a motion to that effect adopted by an absolute majority of the mayor and all council members. 
(Code 1978, § 1-1004; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
1-4-040 - Rules and procedures of council. 
A.  All ordinances passed by the council may contain the following items, if necessary, and should follow the order set forth in this section: 
1.  Ordinance number; 
2.  Title and purpose; 
3.  Ordaining clause; 
4.  Body of ordinance by sections; 
5.  Severability clause; 
6.  Penalty clause; 
7.  Repealing clause; 
8.  Adoption date; 
9.  Effective date; 
10.  Signature of mayor or mayor pro tem; 
11.  Attestation of city clerk; and 
12.  Approval of city attorney as to form. 
B.  If one of the items listed above is not contained in the ordinance or not set forth in the order listed above, this shall not defeat the validity of the ordinance as passed by council. 
C.  Call to Order. The mayor shall take the chair at the hour appointed and call the members of the council to order. He or she shall preserve order and decorum, decide all questions of order, unless appealed to the council. In the absence of the mayor, the mayor pro tem is vested with like powers. In the absence of the mayor and mayor pro tem, the presiding officer shall be vested with the powers of the mayor. If there is no presiding officer in attendance, the council may elect a presiding officer. 
D.  Order of Business. The business of all regular meetings of the council should be transacted in the following order, unless the council by a vote of a majority of the members present, shall suspend the rules and change the order of business: 
1.  Call to order and roll call; 
2.  Invocation; 
3.  Pledge of allegiance; 
4.  Presentations/proclamations; 
5.  Announcements of general community information by the mayor, council, or city manager; 
6.  Scheduled appearances; 
7.  Consent agenda; 
8.  Minutes of the preceding meeting; 
9.  Appointments; 
10.  Ordinances; 
11.  Resolutions; 
12.  City attorney's report; 
13.  City manager's report; 
14.  Mayor's report; 
15.  Committee reports; 
16.  Other business; 
17.  Unscheduled appearances; and 
18.  Adjournment. 
E.  Ordinance and Minute Books. All of the following shall be recorded in the minutes of the council: 
1.  All motions, except for adjournment; 
2.  All resolutions; 
3.  All information required by the laws of the United States and of this state; 
4.  The motion, all ordinances, number and title by which new ordinances are introduced; and 
5.  All other information which council may direct. 
F.  Appointments. All appointments shall be by vote. 
G.  Record of "Yeas," "Nays" and "Abstentions." The "yeas", "nays" and "abstentions" shall be taken electronically and/or by show of hands. 
H.  Addressing Chairman. Each member when the council is convened and organized for business, when speaking, shall address the presiding officer. 
I.  Duties of Clerk. The duties of the clerk shall in no instance, except in case of sickness, or by consent of the council, be performed by proxy or substitute. 
J.  Minutes of Previous Meetings. Before the minutes of any preceding meeting of the council are confirmed, any member may move to reconsider any question, motion, resolution or other matter contained in the minutes of the previous meeting. If the reconsideration is voted for by a majority of the members present, the subject matter of the reconsideration shall be the first business in order to be disposed of. 
K.  Parliamentary Rules. The latest edition of Roberts' Rules of Parliamentary Order, Newly Revised, shall govern the city council in all areas in which such are applicable and in which it is not inconsistent with rules adopted by the council or state or federal law. 
L.  Amendment of Rules and Enactment of Ordinances and Charter Amendments. 
1.  To Amend Rules. These rules may be amended, or new rules adopted by a majority vote of all members of the council. Any such alterations or amendments shall be submitted in writing at a regular meeting and shall be placed on the calendar under the order of new business for the following regular meeting. This requirement shall be waived only by unanimous consent, with a recorded vote of all members of the council. 
2.  Enactment of Ordinances and Charter Amendments. Upon passage of an ordinance or a charter amendment by required majority vote, such ordinance or charter shall automatically be tabled for the purposes of review of construction and to verify no conflicts with other sections or parts of our city charter by the city attorney. Once reviewed by city attorney then forward to the next judicial/legislative committee for final review to be moved forward to following city council meeting for final consideration. This requirement may be waived for urgent reasons when waived by unanimous consent subject to veto. 
Excluded from this document are: zoning applications (including annexations and code amendments related to the zoning application), and budget matters. 
M.  Any person who, during the sitting of the council assembled for and engaged in the study of, or the consideration of the affairs, interests, and problems of the city, or in the enactment of rules, resolutions, motions, or ordinances for the city shall create any disturbance by any noises, conversations, gestures, acts, or conduct that interferes with the orderly considerations and deliberations of the council, thus assembled, shall be guilty of disorderly conduct and may be punished for such upon conviction in the municipal court. 
N.  Special Meetings. When a special meeting is called, a notice of the special session, stating time, place and subject shall be served personally upon each member of the council, the city manager, and the city attorney left in their usual places of residence or other place or by another method as may be designated by the elected official and any such other place shall be located within the City of Marietta at least 24 hours before the time of the meeting. 
O.  Consent Agenda. A portion of the agenda may be designated as a consent agenda and all items contained therein may be voted on en gross. A council member may, without discussion, state that he or she is voting in the affirmative on all of the consent agenda items except certain ones which he or she will name by number. In such cases, the vote of the council member(s) shall be recorded as negative or an abstention for the items named. However, prior to the vote on the consent agenda, any council member may withdraw an item from the consent agenda so that it shall be debated and voted on individually. This shall not limit the right of the council member to abstain. 
P.  Dissents and Protest. Any member who stringently objects to any ordinance, resolution, or other item of business passed by council may have his or her protest or dissent entered upon the council record provided he or she files the protest or objection in writing to the council at the later of the next regular meeting or approval of the minutes for the next regular meeting following the date of passage of the item objected to. 
Q.  Filing Agenda Items. Any member shall have the right to place an ordinance, resolution or document on the council agenda provided same is filed with the city manager by 10:00 on Friday morning preceding the regular council meeting. Except as otherwise provided in this paragraph, no agenda item may be placed on the council agenda after the adjournment of the agenda work session, except by unanimous vote of council members present at the regular council meeting. The city manager or his designee shall have the right to place items on and shall prepare the initial agenda sent to the council. Thereafter, every additional ordinance, resolution or other agenda item placed on the council agenda at the agenda work session shall be approved by an affirmative vote of four members of the city council at agenda work session, or any such item that does not receive objection at said meeting, shall be placed on the agenda for the following regular council meeting. Any item held from the previous special or regular council meeting shall be added to the council agenda. 
R.  Anonymous Communications. Unsigned communications shall not be introduced in council meetings. 
S.  Suspension of Rules. Any provision of these rules not governed by the charter may be temporarily suspended at any meeting by unanimous consent where the chair asks if there are any objections to the suspension of the rules. A single objection will require that a counted vote be taken by yeas and nays and entered upon the records. If a vote is taken and there is a negative vote the rules shall not be suspended. 
T.  Explanations. If a motion has been voted on without discussion and a council member feels that it is necessary to explain his/her vote, he or she may have up to five minutes to give the public reasons for his/her vote. This shall not be construed as an opportunity to repeat discussion that has already taken place at the same meeting. 
U.  Motions. For a motion to be properly considered by council, the motion must be made and then receive a second. 
V.  The council shall have seven committees as follows: 
1.  Economic/Community Development; 
2.  Finance/Investments; 
3.  Judicial/Legislative; 
4.  Parks, Recreation and Tourism; 
5.  Personnel/Insurance; 
6.  Public Safety; 
7.  Public Works. 
    Each council member shall chair one committee, serve as vice-chair of a second committee and serve on a third committee. The mayor shall annually, or as needed if there is a vacancy, make appointments of council members to the committees which are subject to the approval of council. 
W.  Council Gatherings. The city manager is hereby directed to post notices in conformity with the Georgia Open Meetings law regarding informal gatherings following council events from time to time as needed. 
X.  Official Minutes. Once the minutes for any city council meeting or any committee thereof have been prepared and distributed by the city clerk, the minutes shall be deemed to belong to the city council or such committee and no elected official shall request any change to the minutes without: 
1.  The recognition of the presiding officer who shall recognize any member for this purpose before voting on the minutes takes place; and 
2.  The presiding officer, city clerk, or member requesting modification shall read the substance of any requested amendment into the record; and 
3.  Such amendment shall be approved by a vote of the city council or the appropriate committee or as set forth herein. 
Any amendment so offered, if in writing, shall be deemed to be a public record. In addition, any member who requests that the city clerk change, modify or amend any minutes prepared by the city clerk, such change shall be reflected by highlighting any such change suggested by a member and approval of any such change shall be voted upon by the city council or any committee thereof or as set forth herein. In addition, such amendment shall be approved if there is no objection to the amendment or the chair shall announce that there is unanimous consent to such amendment and there is no objection to same. 
Y.  Rules and Procedures. Every term of council shall approve and publish meeting rules and procedures on or before the March city council meeting. In the event the same have not been amended by the said March city council meeting they will be deemed to be reapproved as written. The seated city council as of the approval of this amendment shall approve and publish such rules and procedures on or before August 11, 2011. Publish shall mean a written city council adopted resolution that states the rules and procedures of all city council meetings. Additionally, succinct notations as to public presentations and comments shall be included in the agenda within the meeting and published as notes. These published meeting rules and procedures shall commence with the sitting city council as of January 2010 adopting and publishing such on or before August 11, 2011. 
Z.  Zoning Hearings. All zoning hearings shall be conducted in compliance with Georgia law. In addition, the applicant shall be given 15 minutes to present its case. The opposition shall be given 15 minutes to present its case. Time limits set forth herein may be extended equally to each side by a majority vote of the city council. 
(Code 1978, § 1-1006, Ord. No. 3964, 5/11/1983; Ord. No. 4284, 2/12/1986; Ord. No. 5197, 8/11/1993, § 1-6; Ord. No. 5464, 7/12/1995; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/1996; Ord. No. 5588, 8/14/1996, § 1; Ord. No. 6137, 6/14/2000, § 1; Ord. No. 6341, 12/12/2001, § 1; Ord. No. 6353, 1/9/2002, § 1; Ord. No. 6930, 6/14/2006, § 1; Ord. No. 7469, 6/9/2010, § 1; Ord. No. 7486, 7/14/2010, § 1; Ord. No. 7544, 7/13/2011, § 1; Ord. No. 7583, 3/7/2012, § 1; Ord. No. 7686, 9/11/2013, § 1; Ord. No. 7687, 9/11/2013, § 1; Ord. No. 7869, 2/10/2016, § 1; Ord. No. 8019, 4/11/2018, § 1) 
1-4-050 - Power of mayor and council to subpoena witnesses. 
    The council, when sitting as a judicial or quasi-judicial body pursuant to public law, its charter, or its ordinances, shall compel the attendance of witnesses by subpoena under the same rules as prevail in the superior courts and any witness who shall fail to respond to the subpoena, or who shall refuse to testify under oath, shall be guilty of contempt. 
(Code 1978, § 1-1007; Ord. No. 1500, 2/13/1960, § 1; Code 1961, § 2-9; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/1996) 
1-4-060 - Service of subpoena. 
    The subpoenas as authorized in the preceding section shall bear witness in the name of the mayor; shall be issued by the city clerk; and shall be served by the chief of police, any police officer, or by such other person as the mayor may designate. 
(Code 1978, § 1-1008; Ord. No. 1500, 2/13/1960, § 2; Code 1961, § 2-10; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/1996) 
1-4-070 - Refusal to answer subpoena declared contempt; penalty. 
    Should any person fail to respond to a subpoena of the council, after having been lawfully served, without good cause, or should the person refuse to testify under oath, then the council shall hold the person in contempt, and, in their discretion, punish the person by the imposition of a fine not greater than $25.00 or by incarceration for a period of time not to exceed three days. Each of the failures or refusals herein described shall constitute a separate contempt. 
(Code 1978, § 1-1009; Ord. No. 1500, 2/13/1960, § 4; Code 1961, § 2-12; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/1996) 
1-4-080 - Municipal awards created. 
A.  There is created an award to be known as the distinguished citizens award, which shall be bestowed upon the citizens of this community that have brought distinction upon themselves and thereby upon this community and by their achievement in contributing to the public good through service, accomplishment and dedication to this community. The award shall be made by the city council. 
B.  There is created an award to be known as the distinguished service award which shall be bestowed upon the officials and employees of the city and the officials and employees of its related authorities that have especially and peculiarly through dedication and effort served this city and performed duties that have brought honor and recognition in the performance thereof. The award shall be made by the city council. 
C.  There is created an award to be known as the distinguished valor award which shall be bestowed upon the citizens of this community that have performed heroic deeds of valor in the preservation and saving of property and human life and limb. The award shall be made by the city council. 
(Code 1978, § 1-1010; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
1-4-090 - Travel and training policy. 
A.  No expense shall be paid for travel and training by the mayor and council unless approval is granted by the council in advance. 
B.  Whenever possible, the city will pay directly in advance any airfares, hotel fees or registration fees. All refunds are to be delivered to the finance department. 
C.  Within five working days of returning from any such travel, all persons shall submit an itemized travel expense statement to the finance department. Actual invoices for hotels, registration fees and airline tickets shall be included if they were not prepaid by the city. Receipts for meals, taxis, parking, tips, etc., are not required as such expenses are deemed to be covered by the per diem set by the council. 
D.  An immediate settlement will be made between the person traveling and the finance department for the balance of expenses overpaid or underpaid by the city. 
E.  Failure to comply with any of the above procedures may result in the withholding of any salaries or allowances otherwise due the person until a satisfactory accounting of the travel expense is made. 
F.  Travel expense of spouses or others is expressly ineligible. Only the single room rate will be reimbursed if the spouse or other ineligible persons travel with the employee. However, if the hotel only has double room rates, then such rate is otherwise reimbursable. In the event conditions merit, this rule may be waived by council. 
G.  The city or board of lights and water, in general, will reimburse only necessary and reasonable travel expenses. Exorbitant rates charged by luxury hotels, for example, may not be fully reimbursed if other accommodations were available. Only the tourist class airfare will be reimbursed. First class fares will be allowed only if they were the only available seats on that flight. 
H.  At any time, the city council or board of lights and water may require that persons traveling on city or board business, do so at their own expense, with no travel advances. Persons traveling would thus submit all receipts on the travel expense statement for approval by the city manager. 
(Code 1978, § 1-1011; Ord. No. 3681, 5/14/80; Ord. No. 5173, 6/9/93; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
CHAPTER 1-6 - ELECTIONS 

1-6-010 - Election officials. 
    The city council shall by resolution appoint a municipal election superintendent, election manager, registrars, absentee ballot clerk, and any other officials as are necessary, all of whom shall exercise those powers and duties set forth in O.C.G.A. § 21-3-33 and other applicable provisions of the Georgia Municipal Election Code as now exists or as hereafter amended. 
(Code 1978, § 1-2001; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
1-6-020 - Filing notice of candidacy; date. 
    Filing of notice of candidacy for municipal office shall be conducted in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 21-3-91 as amended. The qualifying period shall commence no earlier than 8:30 a.m. on the second Monday in September immediately preceding the general election and shall end no later than 4:30 p.m. on the following Wednesday. 
(Code 1978, § 1-2002; Ord. No. 4167, 6/12/85; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
1-6-030 - Electors list. 
    The county board of registrars shall deliver to the chief registrar of the municipality, upon a basis mutually agreed upon between the board of registrars and the governing authority of the municipality, a copy of the list of electors for the municipality for the primary or election. Such list shall be delivered at least fourteen (14) days prior to such primary or election for the purpose of permitting the chief registrar to check the accuracy of the list and to challenge the disqualified. The municipal registrar shall, upon receipt of the county registration list, or as soon as practicable thereafter but in no event later than five days prior to such primary or election, purge such list of the names of all persons who will not be qualified to vote at such primary or election. In addition, the county registrars shall provide a list of inactive electors for the municipality. The registrar shall certify such lists and file with the city clerk a copy showing the names of electors entitled to vote at such primary or election in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 21-3-123(e) as amended. 
(Code 1978, § 1-2003; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
1-6-040 - Challenge of name on electors' list. 
    (See O.C.G.A. § 21-3-138 as now exists or as hereafter amended.) 
(Code 1978, § 1-2004; Code 1961, § 2-16.2 as amended by Ord. No. 3057, 10/8/73; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
1-6-050 - Qualification fees. 
    The qualifications fee for candidates filing a notice of candidacy in any general or special election shall be in an amount as set forth in O.C.G.A § 21-3-90 as the same now exists or may hereafter be amended. Said fee shall be received by the municipal election superintendent at the time of filing the notice of candidacy and paid over to the city. 
A.  At least two weeks prior to the opening of qualifications for a special or general election, the city council shall fix and publish a qualification fee, to be paid by candidates seeking election, and such fee shall be paid to the municipal superintendent at the time a candidate files the candidate's notice of candidacy, and paid over to the city. Such fee shall be three percent of the annual salary of the office if a salaried office. If not a salaried office, a reasonable fee shall be set by the city council, not to exceed thirty-five dollars ($35.00) for such office. 
B.  A pauper's affidavit in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 21-3-90 may be filed in lieu of paying the qualifying fee on a form by the Secretary of State. The municipal superintendent shall place on the ballot the name of any candidate who subscribes and swears under oath that such candidate has neither the assets nor the income to pay the qualifying fee. 
(Code 1978, § 1-2005; Ord. No. 4189, 8/14/85; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
1-6-060 - Contested elections. 
    (See O.C.G.A. § 21-3-420 as now exists or as hereafter amended.) 
(Code 1978, § 1-2006; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
1-6-070 - Age to qualify for office lowered to eighteen. 
    Any person eighteen (18) years of age or older shall be qualified and eligible to serve in any elective office of the city. 
(Code 1978, § 1-2007; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
1-6-080 - Wards; polling places; annexed territory. 
A.  There shall be seven wards within the city for election purposes; the boundaries of which shall be maintained on an official map or description in the office of the city clerk and available for inspection by the public and is hereby incorporated herein.

(Code 1978, § 1-2008; Ord. No. 3824, 12/9/81; Ord. No. 5007, 2/12/92, § 1; Ord. No. 5030, 5-13-92, § 1; Ord. No. 5156, 5/12/93, § 1; Ord. No. 5295, 5-11-94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96; Ord. No. 5806, 2/11/98, § 1; Ord. No. 5952, 1/13/1999, § 1; Ord. No. 5982, 5/12/1999, § 1; Ord. No. 6254, 6/13/2001, § 1; Ord. No. 6380, 4/10/2002, § 1; Ord. No. 6562, 8/27/2003, § 1; Ord. No. 6570, 9/10/2003, § 1; Ord. No. 6629, 3/10/2004, § 1; Ord. No. 6802, 5/11/2005, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 6840, 8/10/2005, § 1; Ord. No. 6857, 9/14/2005, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 7117, 12/12/2007, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 7131, 2/13/2008, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 7367, 8/12/2009, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 7523, 3/9/2011, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 7590, 1/11/2012, § 1; Ord. No. 7842, 10/14/2015, § 1; Ord. No. 7875, 5/11/2016, § 1) 
1-6-100 - Optical scan voting system. 
    The City of Marietta approves the use of an optical scan voting system for the computation of votes during future elections within the City of Marietta. 
(Ord. No. 6092, 2/9/2000, § 1) 
CHAPTER 1-6-2 - CIVIL SERVICE BOARD ELECTIONS 

1-6-2-010 - Conduct of Civil Service Board elections, generally. 
    Civil service board elections shall be conducted as provided herein and as now or hereafter amended by ordinance of the city council. 
    Civil service board elections shall be held for three days, Tuesday through Thursday, beginning the second Tuesday in October for Posts 2 and 4 of the board for the terms provided by Section 4.15 of the City Charter. 
    Civil service board elections shall be held in the office of the city clerk from 7:00 a.m. until 4:00 p.m. 
    The purpose of civil service board elections is to nominate individuals to the city council for appointment by the city council to the civil service board as per Part 1, Article IV, Division 2 of the City Charter. "Nominate," as used in this chapter, is a formal but non-binding recommendation to the city council. The city council shall consider, but not be bound by, nominations made as a result of elections or the nominating process. 
(Code 1978, 1-2100; Ord. No. 5498, 10-11-95; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96; Ord. No. 8077, 2/13/2019, § 1) 
1-6-2-020 - Election officials. 
    The city clerk shall serve as the election superintendent and shall appoint any other officials as are necessary for the conduct of the civil service board election. 
(Code 1978, 1-2101; Ord. No. 5498, 10-11-95; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96; Ord. No. 8077, 2/13/2019, § 1) 
1-6-2-030 - Call of the election; notice. 
    The call of the civil service board election shall be made not later than the last week of August. The notice of the call shall be run at least two consecutive weeks in the local newspaper. The call will include the dates, times, and location of the election, and the qualification for candidates. 
(Code 1978, 1-2102; Ord. No. 5498, 10-11-95; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96; Ord. No. 8077, 2/13/2019, § 1) 
1-6-2-040 - Filing notice of candidacy; date; postings. 
    The filing notice of candidacy for Posts 2 and 4 of the civil service board shall be received by the city clerk's office for a two-week period, Monday through Friday, from 9:00 a.m. until 4:00 p.m. beginning the second Monday in September. 
    The filing notice shall include the candidate's biographical sketch. 
    Candidates' filing notices shall be posted on fire and police department bulletin boards. 
(Code 1978, 1-2103; Ord. No. 5498, 10-11-95; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96; Ord. No. 8077, 2/13/2019, § 1) 
1-6-2-050 - Electors to be civil service employees; electors' list. 
    All certified officers who have satisfactorily completed an initial work test period below the rank of police deputy chief of the Marietta Police Department and all certified firefighters who have satisfactorily completed an initial work test period below the rank of fire deputy chief of the Marietta Fire Department shall be eligible to vote in the Marietta Civil Service Board election. Any occupants of the position of deputy chief as of February 12, 1997, are also eligible to vote in the Marietta Civil Service Board election. 
    The director of human resources and risk management and the police chief and fire chief shall certify an accurate list of eligible electors as of the day before the first day that elections are to be held. Such list will be filed with the city clerk 14 calendar days prior to the first day of elections with a copy posted on the official bulletin boards of the police and fire departments. 
(Code 1978, 1-2104; Ord. No. 5498, 10-11-95; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96; Ord. No. 6063, 11/10/1999, § 1; Ord. No. 8077, 2/13/2019, § 1) 
1-6-2-060 - Challenges of names on the electors' list. 
    All challenges to the right of any person whose name appears upon the electors' list shall be filed in writing with the city clerk by 12:00 noon on the Friday before the second Tuesday of October, the first day that elections are to be held. The city clerk will determine whether such individual is eligible to vote and shall notify the challenger, the elector challenged, the chief of the department of such person, and the director of human resources and risk management of the decision and such decision shall be final. Such challenged elector shall not be allowed to vote until such time as a determination of their eligibility is made. 
(Code 1978, 1-2105; Ord. No. 5498, 10-11-95; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96; Ord. No. 6063, 11/10/1999, § 2; Ord. No. 8077, 2/13/2019, § 1) 
1-6-2-070 - Write-in candidates. 
    Write-in candidates must file a notice with the city clerk and local paper within four days following the close of qualifying of their intent to be a write-in candidate. Only candidates that have filed the proper notices shall be allowed to be write-in candidates for the civil service board election. 
(Code 1978, 1-2107; Ord. No. 5498, 10-11-95; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96; Ord. No. 6626, 2/11/2004, § 1; Ord. No. 8077, 2/13/2019, § 1) 
1-6-2-080 - Contested elections. 
    All petitions to contest the results of a civil service board election shall be filed in writing with the city clerk within five days after the results of the election are declared by the city council. Upon filing of the contest petition, a hearing shall be set before the council as soon as practicable. The council shall render its decision within a reasonable time after the hearing, and the decision of the city council shall be considered a final determination of the contest. 
(Code 1978, 1-2108; Ord. No. 5498, 10-11-95; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96; Ord. No. 8077, 2/13/2019, § 1) 
CHAPTER 1-8 - ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICERS 
ARTICLE 1-8-2 - CITY MANAGER 

1-8-2-010 - Responsibility, generally. 
    The city manager shall devote his or her time and attention to the affairs of the city and shall be responsible to the council for the efficient administration of all the affairs of the city over which he or she has jurisdiction. 
(Code 1978, § 1-3002; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
ARTICLE 1-8-4 - CITY CLERK 

1-8-4-010 - City clerk, duties. 
    In addition to the duties of the city clerk under the city charter, the city clerk or employees in the office of the city clerk under his or her direction shall have the following duties: 
A.  To be the custodian of the city seal and affix its impression on documents whenever required; 
B.  To carefully preserve the codes, records and documents belonging to the city where are not assigned to the custody of some other office, and to maintain a proper index to all records and documents so that ready access thereto and use thereof may be had; 
C.  To co-sign, when necessary, disbursements and attest to the city manager's or mayor's signature on all contracts; and 
D.  To perform any other duties as may be assigned to the city clerk by city council or the office of the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1978, § 1-3011; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
ARTICLE 1-8-6 - CITY ATTORNEY 

1-8-6-010 - Powers and duties. 
    The city attorney or assistants under his or her direction, shall be the legal advisor and representative of the city and in that capacity shall: 
A.  Advise the mayor, any council member or the city manager when thereto requested, upon all legal questions arising in the conduct of city business; 
B.  Prepare or revise ordinances when so requested by the council or any committee thereof, and keep the code of ordinances of the city up-to-date and properly indexed; 
C.  Give his or her official opinion upon any legal matter or question submitted by a majority vote of the council; 
D.  Attend any council meetings upon request of any member in their entirety for the purpose of giving the council any legal advice requested by its members; 
E.  Prepare for execution all contracts and instruments to which the city is a party when so requested and approve, as to form, all bonds and city contracts; 
F.  Prepare, when authorized by the city manager, charges and complaints against, and appear in the municipal court in the prosecution of persons charged with a violation of this code or of any regulations and see to the full enforcement of all civil judgments or decrees rendered or entered in favor of the city; 
G.  Defend any and all suits and actions at law or equity brought against the city, unless otherwise directed by council; 
H.  Prepare and file any civil suit or action at law or equity to secure or protect the city's best interest when so ordered by a resolution of the council; 
I.  Make immediate report to the council of the outcome of any litigation in which the city has a direct interest; 
J.  Keep complete and accurate records of the following, which records shall remain the property of the city: 
1.  All suits in which the city had or has an interest, giving the names of the parties, the nature of the action, the disposition of the case or its status, if pending, and the briefs of counsel; and 
2.  All written opinions prepared by the city attorney and all certificates or abstracts of titles furnished by the city attorney to the city, or any department or official thereof; and 
K.  Render any other legal services as may be required by the city council; 
L.  All files are and shall the property of the city upon termination of the contract and shall be turned over to the city or the next city attorney as directed by council. 
(Code 1978, § 1-3021; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
CHAPTER 1-10 - CITY OFFICES, DEPARTMENTS, BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS 
ARTICLE 1-10-2 - OFFICES 

1-10-2-010 - Office of the city manager. 
    The office of the city manager is established in and for the city. This office shall be composed of the city manager and any other employees as may be necessary. The supervision and control of the office is vested in the city manager. 
(Code 1978, § 1-4001; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
1-10-2-020 - Office of the city clerk. 
    The office of the city clerk is established in and for the city. This office shall be composed of the city clerk and any other employees as may be necessary. Subject to the direction of the city council, the supervision and control of the office is vested in the city clerk. 
(Code 1978, § 1-4002; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
1-10-2-030 - Office of the city attorney. 
    The office of the city attorney is established in and for the city. This office shall be composed of the city attorney and any other employees as may be necessary. Subject to the direction of the city council. 
(Code 1978, § 1-4003; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96)

ARTICLE 1-10-6 - BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS 

1-10-6-010 - State created boards, commissions and authorities. 
    The following are the various boards, commissions and authorities created by state law in or for the city: 
A.  Board of Education of the City of Marietta; 
B.  Marietta Board of Lights and Water; 
C.  Civil Service Board; 
D.  Marietta Housing Authority; 
E.  Cobb-Marietta Water Authority; 
F.  Downtown Marietta Development Authority; 
G.  Downtown Marietta Historic District Board of Review. 
(Code 1978, § 1-4041; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
1-10-6-020 - Americans with Disabilities advisory board. 
A.  An Americans with Disabilities advisory board is created and established. The purpose of this board is to provide commentary and technical assistance to the city council in regard to the city's self evaluation process and transition plan in compliance with the Americans with Disabilities Act. 
B.  The ADA advisory board shall consist of eight members of which seven members shall be either: 
1.  Residents of the City of Marietta; or 
2.  Residents of Cobb County who also reside within a ten-mile distance from the corporate limits of the City of Marietta; or 
3.  Any eligible individual who is employed by an organization located within the corporate limits of the City of Marietta. Such members shall be appointed by the mayor and city council. The eight members of the ADA advisory board shall serve for the terms set forth herein: 
Posts 1 and 4: These members shall serve an initial one-year term. Thereafter, all subsequent appointments shall be for a three-year term. 
Posts 2 and 5: These members shall serve an initial two-year term. Thereafter, all subsequent appointments shall be for a three-year term. 
Posts 3, 6 and 7: These members shall serve an initial three-year term. Thereafter, all subsequent appointments shall be for a three-year term. 
Post 8: This post is reserved for the member of the council who is appointed by the mayor as chairman of the city council's personnel committee. This member shall serve a term equivalent to the length of appointment as chairman of the city council personnel committee. 
4.  The ADA advisory board shall have as its chairman, the member of the city council who is appointed by the mayor as the chairman of the council personnel committee. All other committee members shall be either representative of the disabled community or an advocate of the disabled. 
5.  Members of the board shall serve for no compensation. 
6.  The board shall elect its secretary from among its members or request city staff to fulfill that function on behalf of the board. The board shall meet whenever called by the chairman, and shall make its own rules of procedure. All meetings of the board at which official action is taken shall be open to the public and all records of the board shall be a public record. 
7.  Four members of the board shall constitute a quorum of the advisory board. Any vacancy in membership shall be filled for the unexpired term by the mayor and city council. The mayor and council shall have the authority to remove any member for cause or written charges, after a public hearing. 
(Code 1978, § 1-4050; Ord. No. 5062, 7/8/92, § 1-5; Ord. No. 5253, 1/12/94, § 1; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96; Ord. No. 6755, 12/8/2004, § 1; Ord. No. 6898, 3/8/2006, § 1) 
1-10-6-030 - Board of appeals-Construction, building, electric, plumbing. 
    The board of appeals for construction shall consist of seven members appointed by the city council. Each member shall live in a separate ward of the city so that at all times each and every ward shall be represented on the board. Should a member move from the ward or become unable to serve, his or her successor shall be appointed by the council for the remainder of the unexpired term. In the event of reapportionment, any member or members shall continue to serve their term until the first city council meeting in January following reapportionment at which time the member or members shall be appointed from the vacant ward or wards. Present members, as of December 1993, not representing their ward due to reapportionment shall continue to serve until the first city council meeting in January of 1996. No elected official or holder of any other public office shall be eligible to serve on the board. All members shall be appointed for five-year terms unless serving an unexpired term. The expiration date of all appointments, both present and future terms of office, shall be January 31. 
(Code 1978, § 1-4042; Ord. No. 3607, 6/13/79, § 1; Ord. No. 3833, 1/20/82, § 1; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
1-10-6-040 - Board of zoning appeals. 
    There is established a board of zoning appeals for the city which shall have any powers and duties as may be granted by this code. 
(Code 1978, § 1-4044; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
1-10-6-050 - Litigation management committee. 
A.  There is hereby created and established a committee within the City of Marietta entitled "Litigation Management Committee" with the charge of carrying out the matters set forth in this section. 
B.  The committee shall consist of the mayor of the City of Marietta as chairman, the chair of the personnel and insurance committee of the City of Marietta and the chair of the public works committee of the City of Marietta. Any vacancies on said committee occurring by virtue of a conflict, resignation or otherwise shall be filled by a vote of a majority of the Marietta City Council. 
C.  The litigation management committee is hereby authorized to carry out the following matters related to the purposes for which this section has been created: 
1.  To engage special legal counsel, if and where deemed appropriate, to advise and defend the City of Marietta related to any pending or potential litigation against the City of Marietta. 
2.  To request any legal opinion deemed necessary or appropriate by the litigation management committee from the Attorney General of the State of Georgia, the State Bar of the State of Georgia or other appropriate entity. 
3.  To respond to any demand letters received by the City of Marietta, Constitutional Challenges received by the City of Marietta or other matters which attempt to create liability upon the city, any of its agencies or employees or officers or which challenge or seek to challenge any action by the City of Marietta. 
4.  To meet, respond, convene, take action and/or assemble based upon receipt of any notice, correspondence or other notice or suit. 
5.  To make decisions related to any pending or potential litigation and to make decisions related to any matter set forth in this section, including the right to authorize any appeal related to any matter described in this section. 
6.  To report to the city council at any time deemed advisable by the litigation management committee or pursuant to a request by the city council. 
7.  To take any other or further action as deemed necessary or appropriate related to any pending or potential litigation or any matter related to this section. 
8.  To make all decisions regarding the method of defending any suits, including the right to file any counterclaim, and the right to make all of the day-to-day management decisions regarding the litigation subject, however, to the fact that any final settlement shall be brought back to the mayor and council for review and final approval. 
D.  The activities of the litigation management committee shall be conducted in compliance with the Georgia Open Meetings Law and the Georgia Open Records Act. 
E.  The litigation management committee shall be a permanent committee and is hereby authorized to commence immediately upon passage of this section by the Marietta City Council. 
F.  Notwithstanding anything contained herein and except as provided herein, this section is not intended to alter or change the current system by which the City of Marietta handles claims, suits and/or other legal matters which are not brought by elected or appointed officials of the City of Marietta. 
(Ord. No. 7527, 3/29/2011, § 1) 
1-10-6-060 - Clean city commission. 
A.  A clean city commission is created for the purpose of assisting the city council in establishing a city-wide policy for decreasing the amount of loose refuse in the city. 
B.  The mayor and council shall each appoint one person to the clean city commission for a two-year term. The remaining members of the commission shall appoint 12 at-large members to the commission for a term of two years. The commission shall adopt such rules and bylaws as necessary for their operation. 
C.  The clean city commission executive director shall be an employee of the city and be the nonvoting secretary. The executive director shall perform duties as the commission deems necessary and consistent with the responsibilities of the commission and the city. 
(Code 1978, § 1-4049; Ord. No. 3941, 2/9/83; Ord. No. 4852, 12/12/90, § 1; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
1-10-6-070 - Ethics committee. 
    (See section 1-14-4-010, Ordinance No. 3626 and Ordinance 3638) 
(Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
1-10-6-080 - Marietta Development Authority. 
A.  Purpose. To develop and promote for the public good and general welfare, trade, commerce, industry and employment opportunities in the City of Marietta. 
B.  Membership. The Marietta Development Authority shall consist of seven members appointed by city council which shall serve as the board of directors of the Marietta Development Authority. Each member must be a taxpayer residing in the City of Marietta. 
C.  Terms of Office. Posts 1 and 2 shall be appointed for two-year terms; Posts 3 and 4 shall be appointed by four-year terms; Posts 5, 6 and 7 shall be appointed for six-year terms. If at the end of any term of office of any director a successor thereto shall not have been appointed, then the director whose term of office shall have expired shall continue to hold office until a successor shall be so appointed. 
(Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
1-10-6-090 - Pension board. 
    (See Part 4 of the City Code, Chapter 4, Article X-Ordinance No. 4022 and Ordinance No. 4532) 
(Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
1-10-6-100 - Planning commission. 
A.  Membership. The planning commission of the city shall consist of seven members appointed by the council. Each member shall live in a separate ward of the city so that at all times each and every ward shall be represented on the commission. Should a member move from the ward or become unable to serve, his or her successor shall be appointed by the council for the remainder of the unexpired term. No elected official or holder of any other public office shall be eligible to serve on the commission. 
B.  Term of Office. All members shall be appointed for three-year terms unless serving an unexpired term. 
C.  Removal of Members. The council shall also have the authority to remove any member for cause, on written charges, after a public hearing. Compensation may be granted to members in connection with their official duties, as determined by the council. 
D.  Organization, Rules. The planning commission shall elect its presiding officer from among its members. The term of the presiding officer shall be one year with eligibility for reelection. The planning commission shall appoint a secretary who may be an officer or employee of the municipality. The planning commission shall operate under the Robert's Rules of Order. Such rules may be modified upon approval by city council. All meetings of the planning commission, at which official action is taken, shall be open to the public and all records of the planning commission shall be a public record. 
E.  Powers and Duties. From and after the time when the planning commission shall have organized and selected its officers and shall have adopted its rules of procedure, then the planning commission shall have all the powers, duties and responsibilities as follows: 
1.  It shall be the function and duty of the municipal planning commission to make such careful and comprehensive surveys and studies of existing conditions and probably future developments and to prepare such plans for physical, social, and economic growth as will best promote the public health, safety, convenience, prosperity, or the general welfare as well as efficiency and economy in the development of its political jurisdiction. In particular, the planning commission shall have the power and duty to: 
a.  Review and recommend for adoption to the appropriate governing authority or authorities a comprehensive plan, amendments or parts thereof for the development of its political jurisdiction. 
b.  Review and recommend for adoption to the appropriate governing authority or authorities a zoning ordinance or resolution and map for its political jurisdiction. 
c.  Review and recommend for adoption to the appropriate governing authority or authorities regulations for the subdivision of land within its political jurisdiction, and to administer the regulations that may be adopted. 
d.  Review and recommend for adoption to the appropriate governing authority or authorities, a plat or plats or an official map showing the exact location of the boundary lines of existing, proposed, extended, widened or narrowed streets, public open spaces or public building sites, together with regulations to control the erection of buildings or other structures within such lines, within its political jurisdiction or a specified portion thereof. 
e.  Review and recommend to the council policies, ordinances, administrative procedures, and other means for carrying out plans in a coordinated and efficient manner. In addition, unincorporated areas adjacent to municipalities may be added to and included in the area under the jurisdiction of a municipal planning commission for general planning and for master planning preparation and for the preparation and administration of zoning ordinances or resolutions, land subdivision regulations, and official maps, provided that the governing bodies of the county and the municipality shall agree to the boundaries of such additional areas, procedures for joint action, procedures for the adoption of administration of ordinances and resolutions, and regulations applying to the area, and the manner of obtaining equitable representation on the municipal planning commission and board of zoning appeals. Such agreement shall be formerly established by appropriate official action by the governing authorities involved. 
2.  The planning commission, its members and employees, in the performance of its functions, may enter upon any land, make examinations and surveys, and place and maintain necessary monuments and marks. In the event that any member of the planning commission should cause damage or injury while on the premises of any applicant or on the adjoining premises and said official acts outside the scope of the duties of a member of the planning commission, the member of the planning commission shall be responsible for such damage or injury. In general, the planning commission shall have such powers as may be necessary to enable it to perform its functions and promote the planning of its political jurisdiction. 
F.  The attorney for the board of zoning appeals and the planning commission shall be served and advised by a common attorney as engaged by the city with concurrent advisement from said two boards. Current serving city attorney may be considered to represent concurrently one or both of said boards. 
(Code 1978, § 1-4043; Ord. No. 3337, 11/9/77, §§ 1-5; Ord. No. 5566, 6/12/96; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96; Ord. No. 8004, 2/14/2018, § 1) 
1-10-6-110 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 8006, § 1, adopted Feb. 14, 2018, repealed § 1-10-6-110, which pertained to Marietta Redevelopment Task Force and derived from Ord. No. 6423, adopted July 10, 2002. 
1-10-6-115 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 8006, § 1, adopted Feb. 14, 2018, repealed § 1-10-6-115, which pertained to height guidance for Historic Marietta Square Task Force and derived from Ord. No. 7484, adopted July 14, 2010. 
1-10-6-120 - Compensation generally. 
A.  The sum of $75.00 shall be paid to each member of the following boards and commissions not to exceed once a month for actually attending regularly scheduled meetings: 
1.  Board of appeals for construction. 
B.  The sum of $125.00 per month shall be paid to each member of the following boards and commissions: 
1.  Board of zoning appeals; and 
2.  Civil service board. 
C.  The sum of $175.00 per month shall be paid to each member of the following boards and commission: 
1.  Planning commission. 
D.  The sum of $350.00 per month shall be paid to each member of the following boards and commissions: 
1.  Marietta Board of Lights and Water. 
(Code 1978, § 1-4048; Ord. No. 3296, 4/13/77; Ord. No. 3607, 6/13/79, § 1; Ord. No. 3669, 3/12/80; Mo. of 8/8/84; Ord. No. 4200, 9/11/85; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96; Ord. No. 6215, 2/14/2001, § 1; Ord. No. 7902, 7/13/2016, § 1) 
1-10-6-130 - Procurement of services. 
    No board, office or department of the city may hire any person/corporation or procure any services for or on behalf of the city without the approval of city council. 
(Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
1-10-6-140 - Rules of boards and commissions. 
    All boards and commissions created by this chapter shall operate under the Robert's Rules of Order as modified by the city council's rules and regulations. Such rules may be modified only upon approval by city council. 
(Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
1-10-6-150 - Appointment process. 
A.  Application: 
1.  Develop and implement a website that describes all City of Marietta authorities, boards and commissions. 
2.  A detailed general application form for people who want to volunteer to serve the city should be developed and made available on the City of Marietta web page that can be filled out online. Upon request the form would be sent by U.S. Mail or fax. Applications should be kept on file by the city for two years. 
B.  New Member Agreement: Each appointee shall fill out and sign an agreement form in which they agree to comply with the attendance requirements, attend an orientation and read any other related material, follow the conflict of interest statement, abide by the Marietta Code of Ethics and follow any other legal requirements of their service. 
C.  Nominations and Appointments: 
1.  Current authority, board or commission members, having served one term, must reapply to serve a second, consecutive term. For ward appointments, the member may indicate desire to serve another term to the appointing councilperson. 
2.  The personnel committee could serve as a nominating committee only in the case of nonward appointments made by the entire council. 
D.  Staff Liaisons: 
1.  The city manager will appoint a senior member of city staff to be a liaison with each authority, board or commission. The liaison should be familiar with the role of the assigned authority, board or commission in city government affairs. The staff liaison for each authority, board or commission should prepare an orientation manual and conduct an orientation session for each new member within 30 days of appointment. Such manual shall be presented to city council for review. 
2.  The city clerk will monitor upcoming vacancies and shall be responsible for preparing standard notices of availability to city council. 
E.  Attendance Requirements: When a member misses 25 percent of the regularly scheduled meetings over any 12-month period, which period commences on the date of appointment, the staff liaison will send the member a letter advising him/her that further absences may be cause for his/her removal from the authority, board or commission. Members must attend at least 75 percent of any board, authority or commission meeting to be counted as present. In the case of an authority, board or commission that does not hold regular meetings but meet as required, when a member misses 50 percent of the called meetings over a three-year period, which period commences on the date of appointment, the staff liaison will send the member a letter advising him/her that further absences may be cause for his/her removal from the authority, board or commission. The staff liaison will be responsible for submitting attendance reports to the city clerk. The city clerk will compile the attendance reports for submission to city council every six months, unless directed otherwise. The city council may take appropriate action including, but not limited to, excusing the absences, removing the board member or commissioner, or take other action, as the council deems appropriate. 
F.  Conflict of Interest: Conflict of Interest Standards and the Marietta Code of Ethics will apply to decisions in which any authority, board or commission member or his/her family member has a financial interest or direct personal interest in the outcome of a decision. A member having such a conflict of interest must disclose it in writing and shall recuse himself/herself from voting. 
G.  End of Term Appreciation: The mayor and council should provide each authority, board or commission member a certificate of appreciation when his or her term ends. 
(Ord. No. 6512, 5/14/2003, § 1) 
CHAPTER 1-12 - MUNICIPAL COURT 

1-12-010 - Sessions of court; when held, generally; opening announcement. 
    A regular session of the municipal court shall be held at least twice each month at a fixed hour of a fixed day as may be determined by the chief judge; provided, any session may be dispensed with when there is no business pending in the court or no cases are ready for trial. 
(Code 1978, § 1-5001; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
1-12-020 - Special sessions of court. 
    The municipal court may hold special sessions when, in any municipal judge's opinion, it is necessary or there is urgent cause for the trial of accused persons before the next regular sitting of the court. The necessity or urgency of the cause shall be presumed from the fact of a session being held. All defendants shall have at least six hours notice of the session unless such notice is waived by the defendant. 
(Code 1978, § 1-5002; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
1-12-030 - Police attendance. 
    It shall be the duty of some member of the police force designated by the chief municipal judge, with the consent of the police chief, to attend each session of the municipal court to act as bailiff, and the duty of each police officer making the arrest or having knowledge of the case for or against the defendant, to attend the trial of any person brought before the court. 
(Code 1978, § 1-5003; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
1-12-040 - Clerk of court; associate judge; assistant prosecuting attorney. 
A.  The position of clerk of the municipal court is created. The clerk shall be appointed by the city manager. 
B.  The clerk of court shall: 
1.  Prepare all subpoenas and warrants and maintain a docket thereof that will show the name of the person for whom the subpoena or warrant was issued, its date, at whose instance it was issued, and to whom delivered; 
2.  The chief municipal judge may require that the clerk maintain a duplicate court docket and to use the signed duplicate copy of the docket to make necessary entries in the master docket after each session of court. The master or original to be retained by the judge and the duplicate to be examined for completeness and signed by the judge; 
3.  Be authorized to make continuations of a case for good cause shown; 
4.  Act as court officer to accept filing of all pleadings and motions; 
5.  Indicate time and date of receipt; 
6.  Schedule hearings upon motions when necessary and notify parties and witnesses; 
7.  Open files with copy of original citations for prosecuting attorney in cases where motions are filed and act as custodian of these files; 
8.  Act as custodian of the seal of the court; 
9.  Certify copies of citations, orders and sentences where necessary; and 
10.  The clerk of court shall work under the general supervision of the city manager. The city manager shall evaluate the performance of the clerk of court, shall consult with the prosecuting attorney and judge on their evaluation of the clerk of the court's performance, and report the results of the evaluation twice each anniversary year to the mayor and city council. 
The clerk of court shall supervise the functional day to day office activities of all classified municipal court employees including but not limited to the deputy court clerks, probation officers, and prosecuting attorney's secretary. 
It is recognized that the municipal judge and prosecuting attorney shall direct the activities of the employees respectively assigned to them for specific work assignments and procedures; however, the clerk of court shall have supervisory responsibility over all classified employees assigned to the municipal court office to assure that the municipal court budget and provisions of the City Code and Charter as they apply to employee performance and employee conduct will be effectively and consistently administrated. The clerk of court shall, prior to approving vacation leave, compensatory leave and setting hours of work for those classified employees who are assigned to perform specific work activities and procedures for the municipal judge or prosecuting attorney, obtain approval from the municipal judge and prosecuting attorney. The court clerk shall provide the municipal judge and prosecuting attorney a summary twice each fiscal year of the probation officer and prosecuting attorney's secretary's day to day performance relative to attendance, being on time, courtesy, coordinating and working with others in the municipal court. Any complaints of violations of the law or of the provision of the City Code and Charter as they apply to employee performance and employee conduct shall be reported to the clerk of the court or his/her designee who shall notify the municipal judge, prosecuting attorney and city manager. 
11.  Perform other related duties as assigned. 
C.  The deputy clerks of the municipal court shall have the responsibility to: 
1.  Act as custodian of the original citation issued by the police department; 
2.  Act as custodian of the master docket of the court; 
3.  Handle correspondence with the department of public safety regarding cancellation, revocation and suspension of licenses; 
4.  Forward all convictions, bond forfeitures and other disposition reports required by O.C.G.A. § 40-5-53; 
5.  Forward to the department of public safety all licenses received by the court pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 40-5-53; 
6.  Perform other related duties as assigned. 
D.  The position of associate judge of the municipal court is created. 
E.  The position of assistant prosecuting attorney of the municipal court is created. 
F.  The associate judge and the assistant prosecuting attorneys shall have such duties as are set forth in the City Charter, and they shall receive such compensation as is set by the governing authority of the city. 
G.  Compensation for Associate Prosecuting Attorneys. The associate prosecuting attorneys will be paid an hourly rate with a maximum payment of $150.00 per session, $45.00 per hour in court and $35.00 per hour out of court. 
(Code 1978, Sec. 1-5004, as amended by Ord. No. 3875, 6/23/82; Ord. No. 2883, 7/14/82; Ord. No. 5060, 7/8/92 § 1, 2; Ord. No. 5182, 7/14/93, § 1; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96; Ord. No. 7019, 2/14/2007, § 1) 
1-12-050 - Jury trial; bind over. 
A.  All charges cognizable as violations of state laws shall be handled by a commitment hearing, provided however, that they may be adjudicated in the municipal court whenever the court would have jurisdiction over the offense, and the defendant, in writing, waives any right to trial by jury. 
B.  When a defendant is bound over to the appropriate state court, he or she may be released under any of the following methods: 
1.  If the defendant has posted bond to the city, he or she may be released on the same bond; 
2.  If the defendant has not posted bond before being bound over, he or she shall post bond at the county jail book-in and an arraignment notice will then be given to the defendant and the defendant shall be delivered, in person, by the city police to the county authorities. 
(Code 1978, § 1-5005; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
1-12-060 - Appearance bond; procedure for accepting. 
    Offenses against the ordinances of the city shall be bailable as follows: 
A.  The arresting officer, chief of police, municipal judge or any other officer designated by the chief of police, may accept bond of the accused payable to the city conditions upon the appearance of the accused at the next session or any subsequent session of the municipal court as stated in the bond, to answer the charge. 
B.  The bond shall be in writing in an amount as reflected in a schedule established by the chief judge of the municipal court. Cash bonds shall be allowed in the same amount. 
C.  A person arrested for violation of a city ordinance may be released on his or her own recognizance or may deposit, in lieu of an appearance bond, his or her driver's license with the arresting officer, the police chief or a municipal judge, if in any of these officials' determination, the person will appear at the time set for the court appearance in view of the following considerations: 
1.  The seriousness of the offense charged; 
2.  The penalty provided by law; 
3.  The number of charges pending against the defendant; 
4.  The criminal record of the defendant; 
5.  The residence of the defendant and the length of time of residence; 
6.  The defendant's age; 
7.  Marital status and number of children; 
8.  Residency of the relatives of the defendant; 
9.  Employment of defendant (by whom, nature of work and how long employed); 
10.  Former employment; 
11.  Amount of earnings; 
12.  The defendant's character, reputation and previous criminal history; 
13.  The defendant's mental condition; and 
14.  Whether the defendant has membership in any clubs or societies, church affiliation and other things which could show that he or she is a responsible member of the community with established community ties. 
D.  Any person released under subsection (C)(3) of this section shall receive a receipt for any driver's license deposited or, if released on the person's own recognizance, shall sign and receive a copy of the citation or ticket describing the violation for which the person was arrested. 
E.  All persons arrested or notified by citation or ticket of parking violations shall be released on their own recognizance. 
(Code 1978, § 1-5006; Ord. No. 4542, 3/11/1987; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/1996) 
1-12-070 - Continuance of cases. 
    Continuances shall be made only for good cause shown. Prior to the scheduled court appearance, the clerk of court or a designee of the municipal judge may grant continuations of a case. 
(Code 1978, § 1-5007; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/1996) 
1-12-080 - Forfeiture of appearance bonds. 
A.  The presiding municipal judge or a designee shall call the case, and, if the accused is not in court and does not answer the call, and, if no good and sufficient reason is given for non-appearance, the judge shall enter on the docket where the case is stated "bond forfeited," or similar words. 
B.  Upon forfeiture of any bond, the cash deposited as security shall be paid to the clerk of court, and it shall become the property of the city. 
C.  Upon the forfeiture of any bond signed by a person as surety, the clerk shall issue an execution against the principal and surety on the bond for the amount thereof which shall be collected as tax executions are collected. 
(Code 1978, § 1-5008; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/1996) 
1-12-090 - Pleas. 
A.  The defendant shall enter one of the following pleas: 
1.  Guilty; 
2.  Not guilty; 
3.  Nolo contendere (with the permission of the court); or 
B.  If the defendant refuses to enter a plea, the court shall enter a plea of not guilty and set the case down for trial. 
(Code 1978, § 1-5010; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/1996) 
1-12-100 - Fines; enforcement by levy and execution; payment in advance of court date. 
A.  For fines that may be due by any defendant, execution may be issued by the court clerk and collected as provided by law. 
B.  Persons charged with traffic violations on the schedule, proposed by the municipal court judge and subject to approval by city council, may plead guilty in writing and pay the fine set forth on the schedule prior to the time of their court appearance. Any person charged with a traffic violation not on the schedule shall be required to appear before the court for disposition of the case. 
(Code 1978, § 1-5011; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/1996) 
1-12-110 - Appearance of complaining witnesses; subpoena of witnesses. 
A.  A material or complaining witness in any contested prosecution shall appear at the session at which the prosecution is docketed. The prosecution may be dismissed if the material witness fails to appear. 
B.  The attendance of witnesses may be enforced by subpoena. 
(Code 1978, § 1-5012; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/1996) 
1-12-120 - Rules of evidence. 
    The rules of evidence shall be applicable in the trial of all cases. 
(Code 1978, § 1-5013; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/1996) 
1-12-130 - Judgment and sentences. 
    Upon a judgment or plea of guilty the court shall impose sentence. The court may: 
A.  Impose a fine, with or without a commitment for confinement, compulsory work or both; 
B.  Commit the defendant to confinement, compulsory work or both; 
C.  Suspend the execution of the sentence in whole or in part; 
D.  Defer the execution of the sentence or any portion or portions thereof to one or more fixed dates in the future; or 
E.  Impose any sentence otherwise authorized by law. 
(Code 1978, § 1-5014; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/1996) 
1-12-140 - Court dates; contempt warrants. 
A.  The police chief, or city police officers under the direction of the police chief, may place upon the municipal court docket the names of all persons violating any of the municipal ordinances and arrest and take into custody all persons who violate any of the city ordinances, state or federal laws. 
B.  Court date may be made known to the defendant at the time of the arrest process and shall be properly indicated on the copy of charges given to the defendant by the arresting officer. The charges issued by the arresting officer may thereafter be amended. 
C.  Arrest warrant for contempt of court charges may be issued following each session of court. 
(Code 1978, § 1-5015; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/1996) 
1-12-150 - Appearance before the court of persons served with charges; failure to appear; penalty. 
A.  In any case where any person is charged with the violation of any of the provisions of this code or any other ordinances of the city or any offenses the municipal court has been granted jurisdiction to try and dispose and a copy of charges or other citations or notices is delivered to the person requiring an appearance before the municipal court of the city at a specified time and place, it shall be the duty of that person to appear at the time and place set out in the charges or citations or notices. 
B.  Any person failing to appear at the time and place set out in the charges or citations or notices shall be guilty of contempt of court punishable by a fine not to exceed $500.00 or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed six months, or by both such fine and imprisonment, per violation. 
(Code 1978, § 1-5016; Code 1952, Ch. 11, § 5; Code 1961, § 13-5; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/1996; Ord. No. 8038, 7/11/2018, § 1) 
1-12-160 - Court costs. 
A.  The costs in all cases tried before the municipal court shall be set at the discretion of the municipal court judge or by resolution of the city council. 
B.  The costs may be charged and collected from the defendant upon conviction at the discretion of the judge. 
(Code 1978, § 1-5017; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
CHAPTER 1-14 - CODE OF ETHICS FOR ELECTED OFFICIALS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 7834, § 1, adopted Aug. 12, 2015, amended Article 1-14-2 in its entirety to read as set out herein. Former Art. 1-14-2, §§ 1-14-2-010-1-14-2-210, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 6919, adopted May 10, 2006, § 1. 

ARTICLE 1-14-2 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

1-14-2-010 - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
A.  "Board member" shall mean any member appointed by the mayor and/or council and serving the city on any board or commission. 
B.  "Business" or "business entity" means any entity, regardless of form, whether or not operated for profit, including, but not limited to, any corporation, general or limited partnership, sole proprietorship, joint venture, association, franchise, firm, institution, trust, person or foundation. 
C.  "Actual knowledge" is knowledge of facts that a person has. 
D.  "Direct contractual interest" is defined as any direct interest that the elected official has in a contract regarding an individual item that is being considered by the city council and from which the elected official receives direct monetary value or other direct financial benefit from such contract that is directly affected by the elected official's vote on said item. 
E.  "District wide" means an ordinance, motion or action which affects an entire category or matter such as a zoning category, a TAD district or a category that encompasses an area or matter that is greater than an individual property. 
F.  "Elected official" means any person who is an elected city official and shall mean the elected members of the city council and the mayor. 
G.  "Employee" or "public employee" means any person, employed full-time or part time by the city government or any city agency. Appointees of boards and commissions of the city shall be considered public employees for the purposes of this section. 
H.  "Employment interest" means a situation where the elected official is employed by a person or entity or the subsidiary of an entity that is seeking a contract or action from the city. Excluded from this definition is employment of an elected official by another governmental entity. 
I.  "Fair market" value as applies to real estate means the appraised value of the property for ad valorem tax purposes. 
J.  "Financial interest" means all direct ownership interests: 
1.  Of any business or subsidiary thereof or investment, exclusive of the individual stocks and bonds in mutual funds, in which the elected official owns a direct ownership interest which interest: 
a.  Is more than five percent of the total interests in such business or investment, exclusive of the individual stocks and bonds in mutual funds; or 
b.  Has a net fair market value of more than $10,000.00. 
2.  In real property with or without improvements thereto owned and/or controlled and/or managed by the elected official having a fair market value of more than $10,000.00; 
3.  Which is directly held by a trust of which the elected official is the trustee of or acting trustee or executor of a will or administrator of an estate and: 
a.  Where the elected official has actual knowledge of such ownership interest; 
b.  Where said trust is for a member of the family of the elected official; and 
c.  Where the trust owns a direct ownership interest which interest: 
(1)  Is more than five percent of the total interests in such business or investment, exclusive of the individual stocks and bonds in mutual funds; 
(2)  Has a net fair market value of more than $10,000.00. 
4.  In real property in the state of Georgia having a fair market value of more than $10,000.00 which is directly held by a trust of which the elected official is the trustee of or acting trustee or beneficiary of the trust or personal representative of an estate and: 
a.  Where the elected official has actual knowledge of such ownership interest; and 
b.  Where said trust is for a member of the family of the elected official. 
5.  Where such ownership interest is directly held by an individual the elected official has or is acting under power of attorney for financial affairs in a fiduciary capacity and: 
a.  Where the elected official has actual knowledge of such ownership interest; 
b.  Where said ownership interest owned by the individual is covered by the power of attorney;
