A.  At all times during the term of the franchise, grantee shall obtain, pay all premiums for and file with the city executed certificates of insurance evidencing the payment of premiums for the following: 
1.  A general comprehensive public liability insurance policy indemnifying, defending and saving harmless the city, its officers, boards, commissions, agents, or employees, from any and all claims by any person whatsoever on account of injury to or death of a person or persons occasioned by the operations of a grantee under franchise herein granted or alleged to have been so caused or occurred with a minimum liability of $300,000.00 applied to one person and $600,000.00 applied to two or more persons. 
2.  Property damage insurance indemnifying, defending and saving harmless the city, its officers, boards, commissions, agents and employees from and against all claims by any person whatsoever for property damage occasioned by the operation of grantee under the franchise herein granted or alleged to have been so caused or occurred with a minimum liability of $250,000.00. 
B.  All of the foregoing insurance contracts shall be in a form satisfactory to the city and shall be issued and maintained by companies authorized to do business in the State of Georgia. All such policies shall require 30 days' written notice to both the city and a grantee prior to any cancellation, nonrenewal or any material change in policy. 
C.  The city shall have the right to increase the amount of insurance required in this section annually which shall be calculated according to the consumer price index for that year in which the increase is proposed. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6007; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-080 - No limitation of liability. 
    No grantee of any franchise under this chapter may receive, require or negotiate for a document or agreement, written or verbal which limits the liability of the grantee when the grantee undertakes work on the private property of a subscriber on the grantee's own motion or when the grantee is required to come upon the private property to repair existing equipment that was defective due to no fault of the subscriber. All other issues of liability shall be governed strictly in accordance with the laws of the State of Georgia and the United States of America. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6008; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-090 - Surety bond. 
A.  A grantee shall maintain and by its acceptance of the franchise specifically agrees that it will maintain throughout the term of the franchise a faithful performance, license and franchise bond running in favor of the city, written by an approved corporate surety in the penal sum of $10,000.00, conditioned that a grantee shall well and truly observe, fulfill and perform each term and condition of the franchise and that in case of any breach of condition of the bond, the amount thereof shall be recoverable from the principal and surety's thereof for all damages resulting from the failure of a grantee to well and faithfully observe and perform provisions of the franchise. 
B.  A grantee shall pay all premiums chargeable for the bond and shall keep the same in force and effect at all times throughout the term of the franchise. 
C.  The bond shall contain a provision that it shall not be terminated or otherwise allowed to expire prior to 90 days after written notice to that effect is given to the city and a grantee herein. 
D.  The bond shall be obtained on or before construction begins and in a form satisfactory to the city and a duplicate copy of it, along with written evidence of payment of the required premiums shall be filed within 60 days of said payment with the city during the term of the franchise. 
E.  The city reserves the right to review the surety bond and increase the amount of the bond by $5,000.00 each successive 24 months if the city determines that it is in the best interest due to grantee's lack of faithful performance in observing, fulfilling or performing any terms or conditions of this franchise ordinance including, but not limited to, construction or nonpayment of franchise fees within any 12-month period. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6009; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-100 - Indemnity. 
    Grantee shall at its sole cost and expense fully indemnify, defend, and save harmless the city, its officers, boards, commissions, and employees against any and all claims, loss, suits, actions, liability, and judgments for damage resulting from or arising out of the death or injury to any person(s), or the loss of or damage to any property or any other damages caused by the acts, errors or omissions on the part of the grantee, its agents, its contractors or employees while installing, operating or maintaining the CATV system, whether or not the act, error or omission complained of is authorized, allowed or prohibited by the franchise and as follows: 
1.  These damages or penalties shall include but shall not be limited to damages arising out of copyright infringement and all other damages arising out of the installation, operation, or maintenance of the CATV System authorized herein, whether or not any act or omission complained of is authorized, allowed, or prohibited by the franchise. 
2.  A grantee shall pay and by its acceptance of the franchise, specifically agrees that it will pay all expenses incurred by the city in defending itself with regard to all damages and penalties mentioned above. These expenses shall include but not be limited to all out of pocket expenses such as attorney fees and all other costs of litigation. 
3.  Nothing herein shall prevent the city from participating in the defense of all claims and actions that could give rise to aforesaid damages or the city and, at its option, may defer entirely to grantee. In any circumstance, whether sole or joint participation in any action or claim, this section shall have full force and effect. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6010; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-110 - Books and records of grantee. 
A.  A grantee shall file with the city public works director a copy, true and accurate, of maps and/or plats of all existing and proposed installations upon the streets. These maps and plats shall conform to the requirements of the city public works director and shall be kept continuously up-to-date. 
B.  A grantee shall continually keep on file with the city clerk a current list of its shareholders holding over three percent of the outstanding stock or interest issued in grantee and its officers with their current addresses. 
C.  All books and records of a grantee concerning its franchise fees and customer complaints within the city shall be made available for inspection and audit by the city within 30 days after any request for such inspection shall be made. 
D.  Copies of all rules, regulations, terms and conditions established by a grantee for the operation of CATV under the franchise shall be filed with the city and at the local office of a grantee. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6011; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-120 - Rates. 
A.  Upon receipt of a franchise pursuant to this chapter, a grantee shall give the city a written notice summarizing its rate schedule for the respective tiers of service and significant ancillary services or equipment it proposes to provide. Thereafter, grantee shall give the city, not less than annually, a current schedule of its rates. 
B.  This chapter shall be subject to any and all future amendments to the Cable Act and other applicable law(s). or regulation(s). In addition to and not withstanding the requirement of the existing Cable Act and other applicable laws and regulations, if there are amendments to the Cable Act or other applicable laws or regulations which would allow regulatory authority over rates within the jurisdiction of the city, the city, if it so desires, shall modify and amend this chapter so as to implement said authority. Upon acceptance of a franchise, grantee expressly acknowledges the city's right to modify this chapter, applicable to existing franchise(s), and to regulate rates if vested in the future with such regulatory power by law and further waives any objections it may have to the modification of this chapter by the city; provided, however, that if the rates within the jurisdiction of the city are increased by the city, the city shall give to grantee(s) 60 days certified written notice prior to the effective date of the increase, and within 20 days of receipt of the notice grantee(s) may make a written request to the city manager for a hearing before council which shall be granted if timely made. Notwithstanding the foregoing, nothing shall prevent council from increasing the rates, if they so desire, as provided herein. 
C.  No charge shall be made to the city for its construction, installation, or use of city channels or for the construction and operation of the coaxial between the city hall location designated by city council and the CATV system headend location in Cobb County. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6012; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-130 - Conditions of street occupancy. 
A.  All transmissions and distribution structures, lines and equipment erected by a grantee within the city shall be so located as to cause minimum interference with the proper use of streets, and to cause minimum interference with the rights and reasonable convenience of property owners who join any of said streets. The CATV system shall be constructed and operated in compliance with all adopted city and national construction and electrical codes and any future construction shall be kept current with new codes. 
B.  Except when absolutely necessary to service a subscriber and not simply because it shall be more convenient, economical or profitable for a grantee to so operate, and then only when expressly permitted in writing by the city public works director, under such conditions as he shall prescribe for the public welfare, a grantee shall not erect or authorize or permit others to erect any poles or facilities within the streets of the city for the conduct of its CATV system but shall use the existing poles and other equipment of the appropriate electrical power and telephone and other utility companies under such terms and agreements as a grantee negotiates with these companies. The city shall cooperate with a grantee in negotiating and obtaining permission to use such facilities. 
C.  No poles, cables, equipment or wires for the construction, maintenance and operation of the CATV system shall be installed or the installation thereof commenced on any existing pole within the City of Marietta until the proposed location, specifications and manner of installation of such cables, equipment and wires shall have been set forth upon a plat or map showing the existing poles, streets, alleys, or highways within the City of Marietta where such installations are proposed and submitted in writing by a grantee to the city electric director and approved by that department in writing. 
D.  Should a grantee be required in the conduct of its business to locate property within the streets of the city other than property which may be attached to utility poles, then in that event, before a grantee shall install or shall permit any other person to install for grantee any of such property in the street, the nature of such property shall be disclosed to the city public works director for his approval as to the need thereof and as to the location within the street and only installed under such conditions as he shall prescribe concerning such location or installation. 
E.  Whenever the city or state shall require the relocation or reinstallation of any property of a grantee in any of the streets of the city, it shall be the obligation of a grantee upon notice of such requirement to immediately remove and relocate or reinstall property as may be reasonably necessary to meet the requirements of the city or state. Such relocation, removal or reinstallation by a grantee shall be at the sole cost of a grantee. 
F.  Whenever in any place within the city, all the electrical and telephone utilities shall be located underground, it shall be the obligation of a grantee to locate or to cause its property to be located underground within such places. If the electric utilities shall be located underground in any place within the city after a grantee shall have previously installed its property, nevertheless, a grantee shall at the same time or immediately thereafter remove and relocate its property also underground in such places. Facilities of a grantee placed underground at the property owner's request in an area where electric utilities or telephone utilities are aerial shall be installed with the additional expense paid by the property owner. 
G.  Grantee shall have the authority to trim trees overhanging the streets of the city so as to prevent the branches of such trees from coming in contact with a grantee's wires and cables. All trimming shall be done under the supervision and direction of the city and at the expense of a grantee. The grantee shall carry the responsibility, including attorney fees and expenses, of litigation of any verdict and judgment arising from cutting of said trees. 
H.  In case of a disturbance of any street caused by a grantee, a grantee shall at its own cost and expense and in a manner approved by the city public works director replace and restore such street in as good a condition as before the work involving such disturbance was done. Provided, that where a cut or disturbance is made in a section of sidewalk paving, rather than replacing only the area cut, a grantee shall replace the full width of the existing walk and length of the section or sections out. A section being determined as that area marked by expansion joints or scoring. 
I.  A grantee shall maintain, repair and keep in good condition for a period of one year following such disturbance all portions of a sidewalk or street disturbed by it or its agents provided such maintenance and repairs shall be made necessary because of defective workmanship of materials supplied by grantee. 
J.  A grantee shall on the request of any person holding a building moving permit issued by the city temporarily raise or lower its wires to permit the moving of such building. The expense of such temporary removal or raising or lowering of the wires shall be paid by the person requesting the same and a grantee shall have the authority to require such payment in advance. A grantee shall be given not less than 48 hours' advance notice to arrange for such temporary wire changes. In the event of a disagreement between a grantee and a holder of a permit, such disagreement will be resolved by the city public works director. 
K.  If at any time in case of fire or disaster in the city it shall become necessary in the judgment of the mayor or the chief of the fire department to cut or move any of the wire cables, amplifiers, appliances or other fixtures of a grantee, this may be done and the repairs thereby rendered necessary shall be made by a grantee, at its own cost and expense and without charge against the city. Grantee shall not be penalized under this chapter for any delays or problems incurred in its cable operation as a result of such action by the city. 
L.  Grantee's work, while in progress, shall be properly executed at all times with suitable barricades, flags, lights, flares, or other devices as are reasonably required to protect all members of the public having occasion to use the portion of the streets involved, or adjacent property. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6013; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-140 - Initial system installation schedule. 
A.  Within 30 days after the acceptance of the franchise, a grantee shall proceed with due diligence to obtain all necessary permits and authorizations which are required in the conduct of its business, including but not limited to any utility joint use attachment agreements, microwave carrier licenses and any other permits, licenses, and authorizations to be granted by duly constituted regulatory agencies having jurisdiction over the operation of CATV Systems or their associated microwave transmission facilities. 
B.  A new grantee shall, within one year from the date a franchise is granted governing cable television operations in and for the city, shall extend energized trunk cable to 20 percent of the city. Completion of energized trunk cable to the remaining part(s) of the city after one year shall be completed as follows: 50 percent after two years, 75 percent after three years, and 100 percent completion after four years. Upon 100 percent completion, grantee shall file a final notice of completion with the city public works director who shall verify that grantee has complied with the build out of its franchise. Upon verification, the public works director shall approve the filing of the notice for purposes of Section 8-24-050(G), "performance bond." 
C.  After four years, an existing grantee shall have completed its system and shall be at a 100 percent extension to the city. Thereafter, an existing grantee shall maintain 100 percent of energized trunk cable to the city. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6014; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-150 - System extension to new subscribers. 
A.  A grantee, whenever it shall receive a request for service from at least five subscribers within 660 feet of its system shall extend such system to such subscriber at no cost to the subscriber for system extension other than the usual connect fees for all subscribers. The 660 feet shall be measured in extension length of grantee's cable required for service located within the public way or easement and shall not include length of necessary service drop to the subscriber's home or premises. 
B.  In addition, the city public works director may upon complaint from any potential subscriber residing in the city order the extension of the system to such subscriber after opportunity for hearing and notice to a grantee. In such cases, the public works director in his discretion, may order such extension to any subscriber only upon reasonable contribution from the subscriber to the cost of said extension. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6015; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-160 - Type and capacity of equipment to be installed. 
    The applicant shall specify in its application the type and capacity of the equipment to be installed and a grantee shall be required by the city to update this section of its proposal in keeping with the advances in the state of the art of CATV systems design. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6016; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-170 - Operational standards. 
A.  The CATV system shall be installed and maintained in accordance with the generally accepted industry standards or generally accepted industry standards in the metropolitan Atlanta area, whichever is greater, to the end that the subscriber may receive the highest and most desirable form of service. 
B.  In determining satisfactory compliance with the provisions of this article, the following, among other things, shall be considered: 
1.  That the CATV system is installed and remains capable of using all band equipment and of passing the entire VHF and FM spectrum and that it shall have the further capability of converting UHF for the distribution to subscribers on the VHF band. 
2.  That the CATV system as installed is capable of transmitting and passing all video signals without the introduction of material degradation of any kind; in other words, whether the picture provided is of a quality considered acceptable in the cable industry at the time, and whether it meets all material technical standards under 47 CFR Ch. 1, subpart K, entitled Technical Standards. 
3.  That the CATV system is designed and capable of 24-hours-a-day continuous operation. 
4.  That the CATV system is capable of and will produce a picture upon any subscriber's television screen in black and white or color (provided the subscriber's television set is capable of producing a color picture) that is undistorted and free from ghost images assuming the technical, standard production television set is in good repair and that the television broadcast signal transmission is satisfactory. In any event, the picture produced shall be as good as the state of the art allows. In addition, the system should be capable of providing proper, undistorted monophonic and stereophonic sound. 
5.  The CATV system shall transmit or distribute signals of adequate strength to produce clear pictures with good sound in all television receivers of all subscribers without causing cross modulation in the cables or interference with other electrical or electronic systems. 
6.  That the CATV system as installed has a minimum capacity of 20 channels. 
C.  A grantee shall render efficient service, make repairs promptly and interrupt service only for such good cause and for the shortest time possible. Such interruptions insofar as possible shall be preceded by notice and shall occur during periods of minimum use of the system. If, for any reason, a grantee's cable systems service is interrupted for a continuous period of more than 24 hours, and the cause of the interruption is solely within the control of the grantee, the grantee shall provide a pro rata credit or refund for the service lost to any subscriber requesting the same. 
D.  A grantee shall maintain an office in the city and availability of a studio within the metro Atlanta area which shall be open during all usual business hours, have necessary listed telephones, and be so operated that complaints and requests for repairs or adjustments may be received at any time. 
E.  At all times a grantee shall maintain an adequate telephone system and personnel capable of promptly answering citizen phone calls. 
1.  During regular business hours the average wait from the time the citizen calls and the contact by grantee's personnel shall not be greater than 120 seconds. Further no citizen shall be asked to hold for more than 120 seconds. 
2.  After regular business hours (defined as 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday) grantee shall, at the very least, maintain an automatic response system that would give the citizen the option to leave a message or wait for personal service. The average wait from the time the citizen calls and contact is made by grantee's personnel or the automatic system, shall be no longer than 120 seconds. 
3.  At all times a grantee shall make substantial efforts to comply with cable industry standards for time periods applicable to answering telephone calls. Should industry standards be more restrictive than the standards set forth herein, the more restrictive standards shall apply. 
F.  Except during installation of underground cable as provided in Section 8-24-190, supervision by the city, Subsection (E)(1), no cable shall be left above ground for more than two days, unless for reasons beyond grantee's control. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6017; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-180 - Public, educational, and governmental (PEG) access channels. 
A.  Upon written request by the city, a grantee must provide without charge one outlet to any city facility and to any public school within the corporate limits of the city existing on the date of this chapter which provides elementary and/or secondary education provided the facility of the above referred to installations is within 400 feet of a trunk cable. Installation beyond the said 400 feet shall be required but the cost of installation for any distance beyond the said 400 feet shall be at the subscriber's expense. Provided that upon application and a showing of good cause by grantee the city council may waive any such installation as referred to in this section. 
B.  That a grantee shall provide at least one free dedicated noncommercial public access channel to be available on a nondiscriminatory basis. 
C.  That a grantee shall reserve at least one channel solely for educational use on a developmental basis, and that upon completion of the basic trunk line, for the first five years thereafter at least one channel will be made available free. 
D.  That a grantee shall reserve at least one channel solely for use by the city, as well as by state and local governments on a developmental basis and that, upon completion of the basic trunk line, for the first five years thereafter at least one channel will remain free. The city shall have priority to the channel over other users. 
E.  Until there is sufficient demand for use of separate PEG channels, grantee may fulfill its obligations under this section on a single channel. For purposes of this section, it shall be presumed that there is sufficient demand for such separate PEG channels when the PEG channel(s) in operation is utilized for the purpose set forth in this section at least 80 percent of the time for an period of at least four consecutive weeks. At such time as there is such demand for an additional PEG channel, grantee shall make such additional PEG channel available; provided, however, under no circumstances shall grantee be obligated to make more than three channels available for PEG use. 
1.  If there is significant unused time on any PEG access channel which the grantee desires to use to provide an additional programming service, then grantee shall give written notice to the city council and city manager of the existence and amount of such significant unused time, together with a substantial summary of its records to demonstrate the same and a proposal for providing additional programming service on the PEG channel(s). The grantee may commence such proposed additional programming service on the PEG channel(s) unless the city council notifies the grantee in writing within 20 days of receipt of the grantee's notice that the city does not consent to such use of the designated PEG channel(s). If the city council gives such notice, then the PEG channels shall not be used by the grantee. If the city council does not give such notice, or otherwise consents to such proposals, then the grantee may make the proposed use of the PEG channel(s) until such time as the city council notifies grantee in writing that such use must be relinquished. If such notice to relinquish is given, the grantee shall relinquish such use of the PEG channel(s) and restore the channel(s) to the originally intended PEG use on the date specified in the city council's notice to relinquish, which shall allow at least 20 days from the date of the notice to the date of relinquishment. 
2.  During unused time on any PEG channel, the grantee shall cause a notice to be displayed on the channel in a form developed in consultation with the city council, informing viewers of the designated use of each such channel, the terms of access and the person (including name and telephone number) to contact to arrange access. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6018; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-190 - Supervision by city. 
A.  A grantee shall construct, operate and maintain the CATV system subject to the supervision of all of the authorities of the city who have jurisdiction in such matters and in strict compliance with all laws, ordinances and departmental rules and regulations. 
B.  The CATV system and all parts thereof shall be subject to the right of periodic inspection by the city. 
C.  The city council may from time to time issue such reasonable rules and regulations for the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city concerning the construction, operation and maintenance of the CATV system as are consistent with the provisions of this chapter. 
D.  If at any time the powers of the city council or any agency or official of the city are transferred by law to any other board, authority, agency or official the transferee shall have the powers, rights and duties previously vested under this chapter or by law in the council or any agency or official of the city. 
E.  No direct charge shall be made to subscribers for normal and routine maintenance. Each grantee shall maintain a service department or personnel who shall: 
1.  Install underground cable within ten working days of receipt of request to install said facilities; 
2.  Respond to subscribers' request for service, advice, and routine inquiries within 24 hours after receipt of the request, including holidays and weekends; 
3.  Notwithstanding Subsection (2), respond and repair any service outage that is within grantee control within 24 hours, including holidays and weekends; 
4.  Respond to any other complaints or inquiries, other than those in Subsections (1), (2) or (3) within 48 hours after the receipt of the request; 
5.  Notwithstanding Subsections (1) through (4), inclusive, if any failure of grantee to carry out its obligations hereunder or to meet time schedules herein shall be due to force majeure, such failure shall be excused and any time deadlines established shall be extended for a period of time equal to the period of delay which resulted from force majeure; 
6.  Grantee shall at all times use diligent efforts to carry out its obligations hereunder in a timely manner. 
F.  Each grantee shall maintain a written record or log as follows: 
1.  Listing the date of any informal citizen complaint relating to the cable system, the name of the complainant, the nature of the informal citizen complaint, and the date and nature of the grantee's response; 
2.  The log is to be maintained at grantee's local business office for a period of two years from the date of the complaint and shall be available for inspection by the public and the city during normal business hours; and 
3.  Grantee shall submit, upon request of the city manager or individual designated by council, said log or record to the city manager for council's review every six months; 
4.  Informal citizen complaints may be made in writing, by telephone or any other form of contract. 
G.  For purposes of this chapter, the term "informal citizen complaint" shall not include routine requests for service, repairs or advice on the operation of a subscriber's converter or television set; provided, however, an informal citizen complaint may relate back to routine request for service, repairs or advice which was not satisfactorily resolved or which arises out of an incident related to the request. 
H.  Any citizen of the city who is not satisfied with the response of grantee(s) to any complaint may complain through written letter to the city public works director who may informally inquire into the complaint in an effort to resolve the matter. The citizen in his letter shall provide to the city public works director the following information: 
1.  The name and address of the complainant; 
2.  The name of the cable system against which the complaint is made; and 
3.  A complete statement of facts upon which the complaint is made. 
    The citizen's letter to the city public works director must be postmarked or hand delivered within 90 days of the original informal complaint to grantee; otherwise, the informal complaint shall be deemed abandoned. 
    If a citizen has received an unsatisfactory result after 30 days from receipt of the citizen's letter by the city public works director, the citizen may file a "formal citizen complaint" in accordance with Section 8-24-320 entitled "Inquiry and complaint procedures." 
(Code 1978, § 8-6019; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-200 - Grantee's duty to remove its properties from the public streets. 
A.  Following a grantee's commencement of service through and over its CATV system, a grantee shall promptly remove from the public streets where its properties are located all or any part of the facilities so located when one or more of the following enumerated conditions occur: 
1.  A grantee ceases to operate the CATV system for a continuous period of six months from the date of said occurrence. 
2.  A grantee fails to construct said system as hereinabove and hereafter provided. 
3.  The franchise is terminated and revoked pursuant to notice as provided herein. 
4.  The franchise is not renewed by the city. 
B.  A grantee shall be entitled to receive notice in writing from the city setting forth one or more of the occurrences hereinabove enumerated or such other occurrence hereinbefore or hereinafter provided and shall have 90 days from the date upon which said notice is received to remove such properties as hereinabove required. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6020; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-210 - Operational reports. 
A.  Within six months from the approval date of a franchise, a grantee shall submit to the public works director an installation plan, for the first year plan, indicating the date on which a grantee expects the installation of the CATV system to be completed and available for service to subscribers in the various areas of the city. 
B.  A grantee shall furnish the city public works director with progress reports indicating in detail the area of construction of the CATV system. Such periodic reports shall be furnished at three-month intervals. The first report to be made three months after the construction commencement date. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6021; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-220 - Cable casting of city and public channels. 
    For the presentation of programming on public channels, a grantee shall make available free time and, if necessary, adequate studio facilities to members of the public at rates subject to council's review and approval. Appropriate technical assistance shall also be furnished by a grantee. Time shall be provided on a first-come, first-served basis, except that a grantee shall endeavor to grant such channel time to as many different persons as is practical, it being the intention of the council that such public channels serve as a significant source of diversified expression. In order that there is a maximum opportunity for freedom of expression by members of the public, such programming shall be free from any control by a grantee as to program content, except as is required to protect a grantee from liability under applicable law. The council may direct that a grantee discontinue, or not deliver, a program on the public channels which it finds to be essentially promotional or otherwise related primarily to the conduct of a business, trade, or profession; provided, however that this provision shall not be construed as a prohibition of advertiser-supported programming on public channels. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6022; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-230 - Removal of facilities upon request. 
    Upon termination of service to any subscriber, a grantee shall promptly remove all of its facilities and equipment from the premises of such subscriber upon his written request. Such removal shall be at no cost to the subscriber. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6023; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-240 - Emergency use of the facilities. 
    In the event of an emergency or disaster, a grantee shall upon request of the mayor make available one channel and its facilities to the city at no cost for emergency use during the period of such emergency or disaster and shall provide such personnel as necessary to properly operate under the circumstances. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6024; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-250 - Compliance with state and federal laws. 
A.  Each grantee shall at all times comply with the applicable provisions of state and federal laws and regulations or any state, federal or local administrative agency. The provisions of this chapter are subject to the relevant provisions of the state and federal law and regulation, including, without limitation, the Cable Act. 
B.  Grantee shall be subject to all city ordinances as set forth herein and grantee shall also be subject to all applicable rules and regulations which, from time to time, may be promulgated by the Federal Communications Commission for CATV systems. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6025; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-260 - Filing communications with regulatory agencies. 
    Copies of all petitions, applications and communications submitted by a grantee to the Federal Communications Commission, Securities and Exchange Commission, or any other federal or state regulatory commission or agency having jurisdiction in respect to any matter affecting CATV operation, shall also be submitted to the city upon request at no charge to the city. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6026; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-270 - Restrictions against assignment. 
A.  Grantee shall not sell, transfer or assign its rights under this chapter and its franchise agreement without submitting to the city of its approval any proposed sale, transfer or assignment. The submittal by the grantee to the city shall be made to the city manager by certified, written notice and the city shall have 90 days from receipt of grantee's submittal to render a decision. The granting of such consent shall in no way constitute a waiver or release of the city's underlying ownership rights in and to its city streets. If no written decision is provided within the 90-day time frame, the grantee's submittal shall be deemed approved. If the city renders a written decision in which it does not consent to the sale, transfer or assignment, grantee specifically agrees that any such transfer shall constitute a material violation of this chapter and its franchise agreement and it shall be null and void. For purpose of this subsection, the term transfer of franchise rights shall include a transfer of control. 
B.  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in Subsection (A) of this section, (i) grantee may transfer its rights under this chapter, and its franchise agreement to any person controlling, controlled by, or under common control with grantee and (ii) grantee may grant to any reputable lender security interest in any or all of the assets of grantee, tangible, including its franchise agreement. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6027; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-280 - Preferential or discriminatory practices prohibited. 
    A grantee shall not as to rates, charges, service facilities, rules, regulations or any other respect make or grant any undue preference or advantage to any person or subject any person to any undue prejudice or disadvantage, provided, however, that nothing in this section shall prevent grantee from conducting certain localized sales or promotional campaigns or from taking reasonable business actions in light of a particular person's credit record or other similar circumstances. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6028; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-290 - Penalties. 
A.  If a grantee fails to comply with, or violates, any material provision of this chapter or its franchise agreement, the city shall have the right to impose certain penalties upon the grantee or, under certain circumstances, to terminate the grantee's franchise and revoke the privileges granted thereunder; provided, however, that all of the following procedures and requirements must be met before any such actions may take place: 
1.  The city shall notify the grantee in writing of any material violation in or failure to comply with a material term of this chapter or its franchise agreement which the city believes has occurred. 
2.  The grantee shall have five business days following receipt of such written notice from the city to respond that it does not believe a material violation has occurred or to commence correction of the alleged violation or failure to comply, and, within a reasonable amount of time, not to exceed five business days unless otherwise extended in writing by the city manager, thereafter as set by the city in its letter, to correct such violation or failure to comply. 
3.  If, after said curative period, the grantee has failed to commence correction of the alleged violation, or failed to correct the violation, as the case may be, or if the grantee disputes the allegation that a material violation has taken place, the city shall schedule a hearing before the council, at which time the grantee shall be provided an opportunity to be heard on the issue of noncompliance with full rights of due process. The grantee shall be afforded at least ten days' written notice of such hearing. 
4.  If, upon the conclusion of said hearing, the council, by majority vote, concludes that the grantee has violated a material provision of this chapter or its franchise agreement, the city manager shall provide the grantee with written notice of the decision and any monetary penalty the council has decided to impose consistent with Subsection (B) of this section. The grantee's surety bond shall act as security for the payment of such penalty until the issue of whether a material violation has taken place has been finally resolved pursuant to this section. 
5.  The grantee shall have 30 days after receiving the council's written decision to pay the penalty then accrued or to appeal the decision of the council to a state or federal court of competent jurisdiction as set forth below. 
B.  As contemplated in this section, the following monetary penalties, not to exceed those set forth below, may be chargeable to the grantee on a per-day basis. Any penalties assessed by the council shall be due and payable, and begin to accrue, as of the date of the council's decision that the grantee has violated a material provision of this chapter or its franchise agreement. 
1.  For failure to commence operations; to provide access channel capacity or facilities; or to fail to meet the operational standards in Section 8-29-270 defined herein, per day $200.00; 
2.  For failure to provide material date, reports, or complaint record or log when requested by the city, per day $50.00; 
3.  For failure to provide material date, reports, or complaint record or log when requested by the city, per day $100.00; 
4.  For failure to extend service to qualifying subscribers, per day $150.00; 
5.  For failure to meet other material requirements, other than failure to make franchise fee payments, per day $75.00; 
6.  For failure to reinstate service within 24 hours after an outage due to conditions within grantee's control, per day $10.00. 
C.  If the grantee does appeal the decision of the council to a court of competent jurisdiction, the decision of the court (including any decisions rendered on appeal) shall be final and binding upon the grantee and the city with respect to all issues involved. Any penalty previously assessed by the city shall not continue to accrue during said court proceedings, unless the grantor prevails on appeal. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6029; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-300 - Revocation. 
A.  In addition to all the rights and powers reserved or pertaining to the city, the city reserves as an additional and as a separate and distinct power, the right to terminate the franchise and all rights and privileges of a grantee hereunder in any of the following events or for any of the following reasons: 
1.  If a grantee practices any fraud or deceit in its conduct or relations under the franchise with the city or subscribers or potential subscribers; and 
2.  If the grantee sells, transfers or assigns its right under this chapter without prior approval, by ordinance or resolution, of the city acting through its council or if the proposed new owner fails to complete the franchise application procedure provided hereinabove. 
3.  If a grantee fails to pay to the city the franchise fees or penalties lawfully accrued under this Code. 
4.  If the grantee has failed to comply with any material provision or provisions of this Code or repeatedly violates a material provision or provisions of this Code or the franchise agreement, provided that the grantee shall first have received written notice of such failure or violation and has failed to cure same within five business days thereafter. 
5.  If the entirety of this chapter or a substantial portion of this chapter shall be finally adjudged by a court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid or unenforceable or substantially invalid or unenforceable; in the event any portion or section of this chapter shall be finally adjudged by a court of law as invalid or unenforceable, and council finds that such provision is material to the continuation of the franchise, the following procedure shall apply: 
a.  In the event council finds that such portion of the stricken ordinance is material, council shall give written notice of its intent to modify the ordinance and the grantee shall have the right to file a declaratory judgment in a court of competent jurisdiction to determine the question of materiality. In the event a court determines that the stricken portion is not material, city council may not revoke the franchise under this section. If, however, the court finds that the stricken provision is material, or if the court refuses to accept jurisdiction over the matter, city council may proceed to amend its ordinance, and any amendment carried out under the terms of this section shall be binding upon the grantee. After receipt of such notice from city council, the parties shall negotiate in good faith in an attempt to amend the ordinance to carry out the intent of this chapter. If the parties are unable to negotiate an amendment within 30 days of the notice of intent to amend, city council shall thereafter have the right to amend this chapter without the consent of the grantee. 
b.  This section shall not affect the rights granted to the city to amend this chapter upon the enactment of certain amendments to the Cable Act as provided elsewhere in the chapter. 
c.  In the event the procedures outlined above do not produce an amendment as provided herein, city council is hereby authorized to revoke the franchise of the grantee. 
B.  A grantee shall not be declared in default or be subject to any sanction under any provision of this chapter in any case in which performance of any such provision is prevented by ordinance, state or federal laws or regulations of the FCC. 
C.  If the city fails to renew or terminates a franchise, the city may consent to the operation of the system by grantee for a period not to exceed 12 months and provide services to survivors in the city as such services may exist on the date of nonrenewal or termination. Upon nonrenewal or termination or thereafter, council shall designate a time at which grantee shall cease to operate service in the city. Council shall give the appropriate notice required by Section 8-24-200 entitled "grantee's duty to remove its properties from the public streets." 
D.  In the event of a violation of this Code or a violation of the franchise agreement and provided the notice requirements and procedural requirements of this Code have been met, the city may seek to revoke the license of the grantee and shall not be first required to impose any penalties authorized under Section 8-24-290. 
E.  No license issued under this Code may be revoked except as provided herein and only after a hearing before the city council for the City of Marietta upon a prior written notice to the grantee of the time, place and purpose of such hearing and a general statement of the reason the license would be revoked. Five days' notice of the hearing shall be deemed reasonable. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6030; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-310 - Periodic review of franchise. 
    On the fifth anniversary of the granting of any franchise under this Code, and every fifth anniversary thereafter, the grantee shall submit to the city a report of the franchise activities for the previous five-year period. The report shall include rates charged by the grantee during the previous five-year period, the service history, a summary of the types of complaints, both formal and informal, made to the grantee during the previous five-year period, and the total number of complaints, as well as all other matters required to be reported hereunder or to the FCC. At the next regularly scheduled city council meeting following the filing of the report or at such other time as designated by city council a public hearing will be held before the council, for the purpose of discussing the report and other concerns relating to the franchise and hearing from the public. The city council shall advise the grantee of any date chosen for the hearing if it is other than the date designated in this chapter, by providing at least ten days' prior notice of the hearing to the grantee. For at least ten days prior to the date of the hearing, the grantee shall run the notice provided herein at least 20 times per day between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m., at least once hourly, on the community channel and the notice shall be substantially in the form as follows: 
"Notice of Public Hearing" 
Discussion of (Grantee's name) 
Service, Rates and Other Matters 
Hearing Before the Marietta City Council 
DATE:___________ 
TIME:___________ 
PLACE:___________ 
    All members of the public are invited to attend and to present to the City Council complaints, suggestions, and other comments regarding (name of Grantee). The Grantee will have an opportunity to respond to their comments. 
    For more information call City Manager's Office at 528-0537." 
(Code 1978, § 8-6031; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-320 - Inquiry and complaint procedures. 
A.  Any inquiry, proceeding, investigation or other action to be taken or proposed to be taken by the city council in regard to the operations of grantee's cable television system other than as provided in subparagraph (C) of this section, shall be taken only after 30 days' public notice of such action or proposed action is published in a local daily or weekly newspaper having general circulation in the city; a copy of such action or proposed action is served on grantee by certified mail to the party designated by grantee to receive service; and the grantee has been given an opportunity to respond in writing and/or at hearing as may be specified by the city council, and general members of the public have been given an opportunity to respond or comment in writing on the action or proposed action. 
B.  The public notice required by this section shall state the action or proposed action to be taken, the time provided for response and the person or persons, in authority to whom such responses should be addressed, and such other procedures as may be specified by the city council. If a hearing is to be held, the public notice shall give the date and time of such hearing, whether public participation will be allowed and the procedures by which such participation may be obtained. The grantee is a necessary party to any hearing conducted in regard to its operations; provided, however, the city is authorized to act when proper service is effected as required under Subsection (A). 
1.  If an informal citizen complaint has failed to be satisfactorily resolved in accordance with Subsection 8-14-190(H), the citizen may file a formal complaint with the city manager of the City of Marietta. The formal citizen complaint shall contain the following information: 
a.  The name and address of the complainant; 
b.  The name of the cable system against which the complaint is made; 
c.  A complete statement of facts upon which the complaint is made; and 
d.  A statement that the citizen has tried to resolve the matter through the city public works director in accordance with Subsection 8-24-190(H). 
(1)  Upon receipt of the "formal citizen complaint," the city manager shall forward a copy to the grantee(s) by written certified notice who shall handle the complaint in a manner satisfactory to the citizen. If grantee(s) refuses or is unable to satisfy the "formal citizen complaint" grantee(s) shall issue a written statement explaining its reasons to complainant within one week of the receipt of the copy from the city manager. 
(2)  When a complaint has not been satisfied pursuant to subparagraph (B)(1) or if grantee(s) fails to timely respond in writing, the citizen may request a hearing before city council by serving upon the city manager written notice to that effect. The citizen must file the request for a hearing within 60 days from the date the informal written letter was received by the city public works director as outlined in Subsection 8-24-190(H), "supervision by the city." A copy of the informal complaint filed with the city public works director, a copy of the "formal citizen complaint" and all correspondence relative to the complaint shall accompany the request for public hearing. If no request for public hearing is filed with the city manager within the 60-day period, the complainant shall be deemed to have abandoned his complaint, and such shall be deemed dismissed. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6032; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-330 - Notice requirements. 
    Grantee shall file with the city manager, the local name and address of the person in Cobb County to whom notice shall be given for purpose of any notice requirements under this chapter. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6033; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-340 - Grantee to have no recourse. 
A.  Except as expressly provided in the franchise, a grantee herein shall have no recourse whatsoever against the city for any loss, cost, or expenses or damage arising out of the provisions or requirements of the franchise or because of the enforcement thereof by the city nor for the failure of the city to have the authority to grant all or any part of the franchise. 
B.  A grantee expressly acknowledges that upon accepting a franchise, it does so relying upon its own investigation and understanding of the power and authority of the city to grant the franchise. 
C.  A grantee by acceptance of the franchise acknowledges that it has not been induced to enter into the franchise by any understanding or promise or other statement whether verbal or written by or on behalf of the city or by any other third person concerning any term or condition of the franchise not expressed herein. 
D.  A grantee further acknowledges by acceptance of the franchise that it has carefully read the terms and conditions hereof and is willing to and does accept all of the risks of the meaning of such terms and conditions and agrees that in the event of any ambiguity therein or in the event of any other dispute over the meaning thereof, no language shall be construed against either party. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6034; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-350 - Failure of city to enforce franchise-No waiver of terms. 
    Subject to the provisions of state or federal law, a grantee shall not be excused from complying with any of the terms and conditions of the franchise by any failure of the city upon any one or more occasions to insist upon or to seek compliance with any such terms or conditions. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6035; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-360 - Time is of the essence. 
    Whenever the franchise shall set forth any time for any act to be performed by or on behalf of a grantee, such time shall be deemed of the essence and any failure of a grantee to perform within time allotted shall always be sufficient grounds for the city to revoke the franchise. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6036; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-370 - Grantee will not contest validity of franchise. 
    Grantee agrees by the acceptance of the franchise that it will not at any time set up against the city in any claim or preceding any condition or term of the franchise as unreasonable, arbitrary or void or that the city had not power or authority to make such term or condition, but shall be required to accept the validity of the terms and conditions of the franchise in their entirety. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6037; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-380 - Rights reserved to city. 
    Without limitation upon the rights which the city might otherwise have, the city does hereby expressly reserve the following rights, powers and authorities: 
1.  To exercise its governmental powers now or hereafter to the full extent that such powers may be vested in or granted to the said city. 
2.  To determine through the council any question of fact relating to the meaning, terms, obligations or other factors of the franchise. 
3.  To grant additional franchises within the city to other persons for the conduct of CATV under the terms and conditions of this chapter. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6038; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-390 - Acceptance. 
    This chapter, as amended, and its terms and provisions shall be accepted by a grantee by a written franchise agreement executed and acknowledged by grantee and filed with the clerk of the city council. Said agreement shall incorporate grantee's written application to the city for the CATV franchise and shall bind grantee to the provisions of said application and this chapter as amended. The council may require a grantee to clarify any portion of its written application prior to final acceptance. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6039; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-400 - Extension of city limit. 
    Upon the annexation of any territory to the city (other than through a governmental consolidation process, as to which the city makes no agreement), the right and franchise hereby granted shall extend to the territory so annexed to the extent the city has authority; and all facilities owned, maintained or operated by grantee, located within, under, or over streets of the territory so annexed shall thereafter be subject to all terms hereof. 
    Grantee shall provide cable service to newly annexed areas within 90 days of written notification of annexation by city subject to conditions set forth in Section 8-24-150. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6040; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-410 - Local office information. 
    During the term of the franchise, and any renewal thereof, the grantee shall maintain within the city a local business office or agent and shall provide the city manager's office with the name, local address and a no toll charge phone number of the agent who will act as grantee's agent to receive complaints regarding quality of service, equipment malfunctions and similar matters. At least once a week grantee shall inform all subscribers by appropriate announcement (e.g., by a slide card) over the systems origination cablecasting channel of the name, local address and phone number of the grantee's agent for the city. 
    The grantee shall maintain publicly listed local telephone numbers that complaints and requests for repairs or adjustments may be received on a 24-hour basis. Response to all complaints will be made within 48 hours. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6041; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-420 - Sale, repair or installment of television sets by grantee prohibited. 
    No grantee shall directly engage in the business of selling, repairing or installing television sets within the city during the term of the franchise. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6042; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-430 - Employment regulations. 
    A grantee shall not refuse to hire or employ, nor bar or discharge from employment, nor discriminate against any person in compensation or in terms, conditions or privileges of employment because of sex, race, creed, color or national origin. This requirement shall apply to, but not be limited to the following: employment, upgrading, demotion or transfer, recruitment advertising; layoff or termination; rates of pay or other forms of compensation; and selection for training. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6043; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
8-24-440 - Chapter subject to O.C.G.A. Section 36-30-3, as amended. 
    This chapter and privilege of a franchise is subject to the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 36-30-3, as amended. If the terms and conditions of this chapter or privilege of a franchise are found to violate O.C.G.A. § 36-30-3, as amended, the franchise shall be deemed to be for that term of years for which the council granting said franchise would have been authorized to grant. 
(Code 1978, § 8-6044; Ord. No. 5390, § 3, 12/20/94; Ord. No. 5575, 6/12/96) 
CHAPTER 8-25 - CABLE SERVICES AND OTHER TELECOMMUNICATIONS SERVICES FRANCHISING 
ARTICLE 8-25-2 - DEFINITIONS 

8-25-2-010 - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings set forth in this Section, unless the context clearly indicates that another meaning is intended. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words used in the plural number include the singular number and words used in the singular number include the plural number. 
1.  "Annual gross revenue." The definition of annual gross revenue shall be the same as "gross receipts" defined in Section 8-4-020 of the Marietta City Code. 
2.  "Cable services" means "cable services" as defined in the Communications Act of 1934, as amended by the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984 and the Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992, and as may be further amended from time to time (the "Cable Act"). In the event that "cable services" is no longer defined in the Cable Act or the definition in the Cable Act otherwise becomes inapplicable, "cable services" shall mean "cable services" as defined in the Cable Act immediately prior to such term no longer being defined in the Cable Act or such definition otherwise becoming inapplicable. 
3.  "Cable system" means any "cable system" as defined in the Cable Act. 
4.  "City" means the City of Marietta. 
5.  "City council" means the city council of the city and its designee or any successor thereto. 
6.  "Franchise" means an initial authorization, or renewal thereof, issued by the city, whether such authorization is designated as a franchise, permit, license, resolution, contract, certificate, agreement or otherwise, which authorized the occupation and use of the streets to provide telecommunications services. 
7.  "Grantee" means the legal entity to which is granted the right, authority and responsibility to construct, install, operate and maintain a system of equipment as necessary to furnish, supply and distribute cable or telecommunications services or both, to inhabitants within the franchise area. 
8.  "May" is permissive. 
9.  "Ordinance" means this chapter and all modifications and amendments thereto. 
10.  "Person" means any individual or any association, firm, partnership; joint venture, corporation or other legally recognized entity, whether for profit or not for profit, but shall not mean the city. 
11.  "Shall" is mandatory, not merely directive. 
12.  "Streets" means the surface of, as well as the spaces above and below, any and all streets, alleyways, avenues, highways, boulevards, driveways, bridges, tunnels, parks, parkways, public grounds or waters, and other public rights-of-way within or belonging to the city. 
13.  "Telecommunications services" means the receipt and/or distribution, through any means, including, without limitation, coaxial cable, optical fiber, or satellite or microwave transmission of one or more audio, voice or data signals. Telecommunications services includes both cable services and noncable telecommunications services. 
(Ord. No. 5886, 8/12/98, § I(1.1)) 
ARTICLE 8-25-4 - GRANTING AUTHORITY AND FRANCHISING PROCEDURE 

8-25-4-010 - Granting authority. 
A.  No person shall provide cable services or operate a cable system without a franchise granted in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and no person shall use or occupy the streets to provide any telecommunications service other than cable services without a franchise granted in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
B.  The city council may grant one or more franchises in accordance with this chapter, provided that the city council reserves the right to modify any provision of this chapter by amendment hereof. 
C.  The grant of any franchise shall be made by adoption of a separate ordinance by the city council and shall be on such terms and conditions as may be specified in said separate ordinance and/or a franchise agreement between the city and the franchisee. 
D.  Any franchise granted shall be nonexclusive. The city specifically reserves the right to grant at any time, such additional franchises as it deems appropriate and/or itself engage in the provision of telecommunications services. 
E.  A franchise may be granted for all or any defined portion of the city and for all or less than all telecommunications services, and for telecommunications services for all or less than all purposes. 
F.  The grant of franchises by the city shall be subject to the provisions of applicable law, such as the provisions in the Communications Act of 1934, as amended, governing cable television franchises and renewals thereof. 
(Ord. No. 5886, 8/12/98, § I(2.1)) 
8-25-4-020 - Franchise applications. 
A.  Applications for franchises shall be submitted in such form and be issued on such terms and conditions as the city council may determine, subject to applicable law. 
B.  Any application for a franchise shall contain and/or require the following information with respect to the proposed franchise and such other information as the city council shall deem necessary or appropriate. 
1.  Applicant's name, address, telephone number, and federal employer identification number or social security number; copy of applicant's corporate charter or partnership agreement as applicable; and any trade names (and registrations) used by applicant; 
2.  A detailed statement of the corporation or business entity organization of the applicant, including but not limited to the following, and to whatever extent required by the city. 
a.  The names and the residence and business addresses of all officers and directors of the applicant; 
b.  The names, residence, and business addresses of all persons and entities having any share of the ownership of the applicant and the respective ownership share of each person or entity; 
c.  The names and address of any parent or subsidiary of the applicant, namely, any other business entity owning or controlling applicant in whole or in part or owned or controlled in whole or in part by the applicant, and a statement describing the nature of any such parent or subsidiary business entity, including but not limited to telecommunications or cable systems owned or controlled by the applicant, its parent, and subsidiary, and the areas served thereby; 
d.  A statement identifying, by place and data, any other cable system or telecommunication franchise(s) awarded to the applicant, its parent or subsidiary; the status of said franchise(s) with respect to completion thereof; the total cost of completion of such franchised cable or telecommunication system(s); and the amount of applicant's and its parent's or subsidiary's resources committed to the completion thereof; 
3.  A detailed description of the proposed plan of operation of the applicant which shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
a.  A description of the cable services and any other telecommunications services proposed to be provided; 
b.  A detailed map indicating all areas proposed to be served, and a proposed time schedule for the installation of all equipment necessary to become operational throughout the entire area to be serviced; 
c.  A statement or schedule setting forth all proposed classifications or rates and charges to be made against subscribers and all rates and charges as to each of said classifications, including installation charges, cable service charges, and any other telecommunications service charges; 
d.  A detailed, informative, and referenced statement describing the actual equipment and operational standards proposed by the applicant; 
e.  A copy of the form of any agreement, undertaking, or other instrument proposed to be entered into between the applicant and any subscriber to cable or telecommunications services; and 
f.  A detailed statement setting forth in its entirety any and all agreements and undertakings, whether formal or informal, written, oral, or implied, existing or proposed to exist between the applicant and any person, firm, or corporation which materially relate or pertain to or depend upon the application and the granting of the franchise; 
4.  A copy of any agreement covering the franchise area, if existing between the applicant and any utility providing for the use of any facilities of the utility, including but not limited to, poles, lines, or conduits; and 
5.  Any other details, statements, supplementary information, or references pertinent to the subject matter of such application which shall be required or requested by the council, or by any other provision of law. 
C.  Nonrefundable Application Fees for New Franchises. No application for a new franchise shall be considered without payment by the applicant of application fees as provided in this section. If a franchise is granted, application fees will not be deemed a credit towards any other fees or sums due by the grantee. If an application is denied, the application fee will not be refunded. 
1.  Purpose of Application Fees. The application fees provided by this section will serve to cover the direct and indirect costs incurred by the city in processing the application, evaluating the applicant, and granting a franchise, and shall include, but not be limited to, administrative, engineering, publication, legal, and consultant's expenses. 
2.  Application Fee. The applicant will be expected to pay the reasonable costs of the city in evaluating the application. Notwithstanding any other requirement of this chapter, each applicant must furnish with its proposal a nonrefundable application fee in the amount of $25,000.00 by certified check or cashier's check made payable to the City of Marietta. 
(Ord. No. 5886, 8/12/98, § I(2.2)) 
8-25-4-030 - Responsibilities of applicants. 
    It shall be the responsibility of each applicant for a franchise to comply with all applicable laws, ordinances, resolutions, rules, regulations and other directives of the city and any federal, state or local governmental authority having jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 5886, 8/12/98, § I(2.3)) 
8-25-4-040 - Public availability of applications. 
    To the extent determined by the city council, applications for franchises, including any additions, modifications or amendments thereto, shall be available for public inspection at a designated city office during normal business hours. 
(Ord. No. 5886, 8/12/98, § I(2.4)) 
8-25-4-050 - Evaluation criteria. 
    In making any determination hereunder as to any application for a franchise, the city council may consider such factors as it deems appropriate and in the public interest, including, without limitation: 
A.  The adequacy of the proposed compensation to be paid to the city, including the value of any facilities and telecommunications services offered by the applicant to the city; 
B.  The legal, financial, technical and other appropriate qualifications of the applicant; 
C.  The ability of the applicant to maintain the property of the city in good condition throughout the term of the franchise; 
D.  The value and efficiency to the city and its residents of the cable services and other telecommunications services to be provided, including the type of telecommunications services to be provided, as well as alternatives to those services and services that may be precluded by the grant of the franchise; 
E.  The willingness and ability of the applicant to meet construction and physical requirements and to abide by all purpose and policy conditions, limitations and requirements with respect to the franchise; and 
F.  Any other public interest factors or considerations deemed pertinent by the city for safeguarding the interests of the city and the public. 
(Ord. No. 5886, 8/12/98, § I(2.5)) 
8-25-4-060 - Procedure for consideration of and action on applications. 
A.  The city may make such investigations and take or authorize the taking of such other steps as the city council deems necessary or appropriate to consider and act on applications for franchises and determine whether a franchise should be granted to an applicant, and may require the applicant to furnish additional information and data for this purpose. In considering applications, the city council may seek advice from other city officials or bodies, from such other advisory bodies as it may establish or determine appropriate, or from the public, and may request the preparation of one or more reports to be submitted to the city council, which may include recommendations with respect to such applications. 
B.  If the city council, after considering such information as it determines to be appropriate, elects to further consider one or more applications, the city council shall set one or more public hearings for consideration of the application(s), fixing and setting forth a day, hour and place certain when and where any persons having any interest therein or objections thereto may file written comments and appear before the city council and be heard, and providing notice of such public hearing(s) in accordance with applicable law. 
C.  The city council may authorize negotiations between city officials and applicants to determine whether the city and such applicants are able to reach agreement on the terms of the proposed franchise. 
D.  Upon completion of the steps deemed appropriate by the city council, the city council may grant the franchise, and may specify the conditions under which the franchise is granted. Alternatively, the city may reject any and all applications from whatever source and whenever received except that a franchising authority may not grant an exclusive franchise and may not unreasonably refuse to award an additional competitive franchise. The city also reserves the right to waive any or all requirements when it determines that the best interests of the city may be served thereby and may, if it so desires, request new or additional proposals. 
(Ord. No. 5886, 8/12/98, § I(2.6)) 
8-25-4-070 - Terms and conditions of franchise. 
A.  The terms and conditions applicable to any franchise granted pursuant to this chapter shall be set forth in the separate ordinance granting the franchise or in a separate written agreement. Such separate ordinance or written agreement, among other things, shall address the following subjects: 
1.  The term of the franchise; 
2.  The franchise area and the cable services and other telecommunications services and purposes of such other telecommunications services, if any, which are the subject of the franchise; 
3.  The compensation to be paid to the city, which may include the payment of fees or the provision of facilities or services, or both; 
4.  The circumstances upon which the franchise may be terminated or canceled; 
5.  The mechanisms, such as performance bonds, security funds or letters of credit, to be put in place to ensure the performance of the franchisee's obligations under the franchise; 
6.  The city's right to inspect the facilities and records of the franchisee; 
7.  Insurance and indemnification requirements applicable to the franchisee; 
8.  The obligation of the franchisee to maintain complete and accurate books of account and records, and the city's inspection rights with respect thereto; 
9.  Provisions to ensure quality workmanship and construction methods; 
10.  Provisions to ensure that the franchisee will comply with all applicable city, state and federal laws, regulations, rules and policies, including without limitation, those related to employment, purchasing and investigations; 
11.  Provisions to ensure adequate oversight and regulation of the franchisee by the city; 
12.  Provisions to restrict the assignment or other transfer of the franchise without the prior written consent of the city; 
13.  Remedies available to the city to protect the city's interest in the event of the franchisee's failure to comply with terms and conditions of the franchise; 
14.  Provisions to ensure that the franchisee will obtain all necessary licenses and permits from, and comply with, all laws, regulations, rules and policies of any governmental body having jurisdiction over the franchisee, including the Federal Communication Commission; 
15.  Provisions to ensure that the franchisee will protect the property of the city and the delivery of public services from damage or interruption of operations resulting from the construction, operation, maintenance, repair or removal of improvements related to the franchise; 
16.  Provisions designed to minimize the extent to which the public use of the streets of the city are disrupted in connection with the construction of improvements relating to the franchise; and 
17.  Such other provisions as the city determines are necessary or appropriate in furtherance of the public interest. 
(Ord. No. 5886, 8/12/98, § I(2.7)) 
ARTICLE 8-25-6 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

8-25-6-010 - Severability. 
    If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or other portion of this chapter is, for any reason, declared invalid, in whole or in part, by any court, agency, commission, legislative body or other authority of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct and independent portion such declaration shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions hereof, which other portions shall continue in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 5886, 8/12/98, § I(3.1)) 
8-25-6-020 - Delegation. 
    Consistent with applicable law, the city council shall have the right to delegate and redelegate, and to revoke any such delegation or redelegation, from time to time, any of its rights or obligations under this chapter to any body, organization or official. Any such delegation, redelegation or revocation, no matter how often made, shall not be deemed an amendment to this chapter or to require the consent of any applicant for a franchise or franchisee. The city council may also establish and appoint one or more advisory boards, with such duration and such number of members as the city council shall determine, to advise it on such of the matters which are the subject of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 5886, 8/12/98, § I(3.2)) 
8-25-6-030 - Written agreement. 
    No franchise granted hereunder shall be effective until the applicant and the city have executed a written agreement setting forth the particular terms and provisions under which the franchisee may occupy and use public rights of way within the City of Marietta. 
(Ord. No. 5886, 8/12/98, § I(3.3))
